TALK.START.PARA: —I table the report `National Policy on Languages' and seek leave to have a statement by the Minister for Education (Senator Ryan) relating to the report incorporated in Hansard.

SPEECH.PARA: Leave granted.
The statement read as follows-
NATIONAL POLICY ON LANGUAGES
Statement by the Minister for Education Senator The Hon. Susan Ryan

I am pleased to table the report `National Policy on Languages'. This report has been long-awaited and long regarded as a most important element in government policy development on a wide range of issues.

I believe that all groups interested in this issue will be impressed by the comprehensive, thoughtful and practical approach adopted in the report. The report was written by one of my Ministerial consultants, Mr Joseph Lo Bianco. Mr Lo Bianco's consultations were exhaustive and his treatment of the issues is consistently intelligent and penetrating. His conclusions and recommendations would carry government policies forward across a broad front. Mr Lo Bianco deserves the highest commendation for his work. The Government will be closely examining his specific recommendations over the coming months in the lead-up to the Budget.

Honourable senators will be aware that, in a speech on 26 April, the Prime Minister stated that the Government endorsed the national language policy. The Prime Minister stated further that the Government is committed to funding an integrated package in the August budget to implement a national policy on languages. The Prime Minister has asked the Minister for Immigration and Ethnic Affairs and me to develop a detailed submission on the shape which that package should take.

`National Policy on Languages' starts from the premise that English is the national language. The report examines in detail ways to improve the teaching of English and to ensure that all groups in the community have effective command of the English language, including adults who need literacy programs. This reiteration of the basic importance of proper teaching and learning of English is welcomed and endorsed by the Government.

The report also rightly emphasises that Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander languages are an irreplaceable part of Australia's national heritage. We do not intend to allow them to die out. My portfolio already has under way a major project on Aboriginal pedagogy, and we will now examine the recommendations in the language report to determine how our programs might best be developed in the field of Aboriginal languages.

Our language policy stresses the importance to Australia of our developing the opportunities for students to learn at least one language other than English. That task matters to us for two particular reasons. The first is that we all have an interest in the maintenance of the community languages of the groups in our ethnic communities. Their languages are part of their heritage and part of our general Australian heritage. They enrich Australia and are an essential dimension of our multicultural society.

The second reason is the importance to the national interest in improving our capacities in languages of national economic interest. Learning Asian languages, especially Japanese and Chinese, is a way of helping guarantee our economic and our trading future. The learning of Asian languages is an indispensable first step to improving our understanding of the region, our trade prospects there and the integration of segments of our economy with economic developments in Asia.

When we develop proposals for discussions with the States on programs for teaching languages other than English, we will naturally seek to ensure that the States prepare balanced and integrated programs which take appropriate account of our two guiding concerns.

I commend this report. All Australians have a direct, personal interest in how we handle the language issue. No question of national importance is unaffected by what we do in our language policies. A narrow or rigid approach to language policy could hobble our policies in many other fields. An imaginative, thoughtful and constructive approach-our approach-will help develop our programs and our potential for years to come.

I wish also to remind honourable senators that we have recently appointed Joseph Lo Bianco, the author of this report, as a full-time Commissioner of the Commonwealth Schools Commission. Mr Lo Bianco will therefore be in the happy position of being charged with the implementation of the report which he himself drafted. Mr Lo Bianco has my full confidence, he enjoys the trust and respect of our ethnic communities, his reputation in the field of education is undisputed. His appointment should therefore be seen as another demonstration of the seriousness of the Government's commitment in this most important area of national policy.

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

SPEECH.PARA: That the Senate take note of the paper.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Teague Sen B.C.

TALK.START.PARA: —I certainly welcome the statement by the Minister for Education (Senator Ryan) that accompanies the report of Mr Lo Bianco, a consultant to the Government, entitled `National Policy on Languages'. This report is the response of the Government to the report of the Standing Committee on Education and the Arts of 2 1/2 years ago entitled `A National Language Policy'. I had the honour to be the first Chairman of that inquiry and to be involved in the initial discussion of its terms of reference, the prosecution of its public hearings and the gathering of evidence from every part of Australia. So it is with considerable pleasure on my part, and I believe on the part of many honourable senators who are involved in that inquiry, that I note the comprehensiveness of the Lo Bianco report and the full way in which the Government has endorsed it. I see that Senator Ryan is in the chamber. She has had the carriage of co-ordinating this matter on behalf of a number of Ministers and I congratulate her on the appointment of that consultant and on the outcome-the report brought down today on the Government's behalf.

SPEECH.PARA: The Lo Bianco report is a comprehensive response to the Senate Committee's report. However, the two-page statement that accompanies it mentions the statement eight days ago by the Prime Minister (Mr Hawke) at a meeting in Melbourne at which he announced one thing about which I am very happy. He announced the Government's endorsement of the Lo Bianco report which amounts to the endorsement of the Senate Standing Committee's findings and the consolidation of so many representations received from all over Australia. I welcome that part. But in the second part of the Prime Minister's speech, referred to in this statement, he announced that the Government has deferred until the August Budget any commitment to the reordering of finances or making available new financial allocations to implement this national policy on languages. We do not see any specific quantitative commitments in the Government's decisions brought before the Parliament today. I entirely welcome the qualitative acceptance of all that I have summarised, but there is an absence of any quantitative or financial measures.

It is reported in the Press that the Minister for Immigration and Ethnic Affairs, Mr Young, and the Minister for Education, Senator Ryan, conscientiously took quantitative recommendations to the Cabinet amounting to some $22m, but the Cabinet turned these down. So we have in this report presented today yet again an absence of solid Government commitment to these important matters. In this financial year, in the last Budget a cut of $28m in the English as a second language program; the merger of the Special Broadcasting Service and the Australian Broadcasting Corporation; the abolition of the Australian Institute of Multicultural Affairs; and the abolition of multicultural education programs in schools were announced. These matters have yet to be redressed and reversed. There is a direct absence of that in the statement that the Government has brought down today.

I am also aware that a wide range of community groups met in February, and again more recently, to respond to the Lo Bianco report. That meeting of all the groups interested in language policy was co-ordinated by the Federation of Ethnic Communities Councils of Australia, and included not only the ethnic communities but Aboriginal communities, academics at the higher education level, linguistic associations, various specialised language groups-such as the Concerned Deaf Group and others with language disabilities-representatives from libraries, the media, translators and interpreters. They put forward some specific recommendations about the decisions involved in implementing the Senate Committee's report, as accepted and summarised by the Lo Bianco report. However, the Government has neglected to respond to any of the items submitted by FECCA. Opposition senators-and, I understand, the Australian Democrats-are concerned that those community groups have been neglected; that their views may have been, in part, represented to the Cabinet by the two active Ministers, but that the Cabinet turned them down. Therefore, we must now look to the Budget in mid-August to know what reordering of financial priorities and new programs will be provided to ensure that the policy is implemented.

There is also the absence of a specific announcement of the Advisory Council on National Language Policy, but I shall come to that point a little later in my remarks. Essentially, the Lo Bianco report, which the Government has endorsed, builds on the foundation of the Senate Committee report. It is a conservative report, in that it takes stock of the language resources that already exist in Australia and of the language programs in which the Commonwealth is directly involved. It gives them a direction to ensure that those resources are conserved and extended. It is conservative in that it acknowledges that there is one national language in Australia, and that is English. It is conservative also, however, in that it recognises the importance of each individual language and allows each individual freely to retain and enrich that language alongside English.

It is not a radical program of legislation for language rights; it is not a radical program that would endorse a particular Aboriginal or community language, from one or other migrant group, and put it alongside English as a language of right in Australia. The Lo Bianco report takes up the context in which so many senators were involved in the original Senate Committee report, by endorsing the fundamental status for English-the Australian version of English-that is our one national language.

Because of that, the report makes the conservative statement that we must ensure that there are programs for every Australian to have access to a full knowledge of English. There is a proper recognition in the report that the States and Territories of Australia have a major initiative in language programs. By and large, the States control the curricula in schools, and it is in that area that there is a major focus on the importance of English for every Australian child, on English as a second language for those who come from families where English is less familiar or even absent, and on English being available at various levels of proficiency for adult Australians-for example, migrants on arrival, where even basic English may be absent, and at various levels of employment and professional work for the extension of English.

The States have an important role in those areas, and that is recognised not only by the Lo Bianco report, with some 100 pages summarising the approach of each of the States and Territories, but by the recognition that there must be a reporting by the Advisory Council not only to the Commonwealth but to the States. It points out that the Commonwealth and States together must work towards the sense of direction that is the national language policy.

I noted in the Minister's tabled statement a warm commendation not only of this report but of its author, Mr Joseph Lo Bianco. As the original initiator of the Senate inquiry, I have looked at the report as carefully as I can, and I wish to endorse all its remarks. I have full confidence in what Mr Lo Bianco has written. I welcome the fact that the Government has appointed him a full time Commissioner of the Commonwealth Schools Commission. I know that he will have a major continuing role in the implementation of this report. I trust that he will be intimately involved in the Advisory Council that is recommended, and now endorsed by the Government.

In congratulating Mr Lo Bianco, I must also mention that hundreds of Australians contributed to his work. They are noted in the appendix to his report, and also in the appendix to the Senate Standing Committee report. Those hundreds of people, with great expertise and experience, made submissions to the Senate Committee and to Joseph Lo Bianco as consultant.

I remind the Senate that it was on 25 May 1982 that I moved the reference of this matter to the Senate Committee. It is now 4 May 1987-a couple of weeks short of five years since then. We now have the Government implementing a major consultant's report responding to the findings of the Senate Committee. It is interesting that the two reports are about the same size and weight with about the same number of pages. The logo on the report tabled today has, in various languages, the word `Australian' written across it, whereas on the Senate report the word `Language', in various languages, is the logo across the cover.

The structure of the Government's response is similar to that of the Senate Committee's report. I endorse that structure. I think it is appropriate and right. I notice that on pages 11 and 12 of the Lo Bianco report there is a direct borrowing of two key tables from the report of the Senate Committee's inquiry. There is one deficiency, however, in the Lo Bianco report. There is no index, which would be a useful addition. There is an index in the Senate report.

These two volumes will be on the shelves of language policy planners in Australia for the next 20 years. They will be a reference for everyone involved in language policy matters. The similarity between the response to the Lo Bianco report and the response to the Senate Committee report is an endorsement by this Government of the advice given by the Senate Committee.

Let me refer to three other matters before I conclude. There are three aspects of the Lo Bianco report, which is of nearly 300 pages, that I would like to note especially. Its structure is very logically and convincingly set out. It firstly talks about the rationale of looking at the development of Australia's language resources. It gives a history of language use and a set of concepts and principles, including those we have recommended in the Senate Committee report, as an introduction to the whole matter. The second part of the report deals directly with policy. It talks about the status of languages, whether they be English, Aboriginal languages, community languages, languages of trade and commerce or languages of intercourse in our region and in the world. It talks about language services such as libraries. It also talks about language interpreting and translating services and other such services. Finally, it contains an important section about an advisory council. The third part of the report, which is about 100 pages long, sets out the approaches taken in the States and the Territories. I endorse the structure of the report. I believe that it is the right approach and I am glad that the Government has also endorsed it.

The second matter I want to refer to is the Advisory Council on National Language Policy, details of which are set out on pages 185 to 188 of the Lo Bianco report. I have read and endorse every word of those few pages. I believe that the Council is a practical and comprehensive instrument for giving advice to this Government, to future governments and to the States and Territories in regard to the wide range of issues which this matter encompasses. Even as a Liberal senator, as one who does not with to see any burgeoning of government or more and more councils and committees, I believe that, in practice, the price of actively endorsing a new program is to ensure that there is the wherewithal to achieve it, that there is a mechanism for consultation and advice. So I directly endorse the four standing committees and the two temporary committees which are to act under the auspices of the Advisory Council. I believe that they directly reflect the Senate's advice. I heartily believe that the detail as to the committees, the terms of reference for the Advisory Council, the suggested membership of the Council and the short term goals of the Council should be fully endorsed.

In the present financial year's Budget $100,000 is set aside to enable such a council to begin its work. I have criticised the Government's response today on the ground that it lacks financial initiative-that is, any commitment of moneys to the implementation of the policy, which has been fully endorsed. I add criticism of the Government not announcing today who the members of the Advisory Council will be. Perhaps the Government wishes to hear the response of the Senate and the other place today and get some public response before going ahead with the appointment of the members of the Advisory Council. I hope that my remarks are taken into account. I urge the Government to press on urgently with the appointment of the persons in the format that is set out on page 187-and the sooner the better. There is money at hand to do so. In the Budget context there can be a fuller announcement as to the provision for the coming financial year.

The appointment of the seven key persons-that is, the chairpersons of the Council, the four standing committees and the two temporary committees-will be vital. There are some two or three outstanding Australians who can fill each of those positions. From the ample number of leading experienced spokespersons there can well be found in the short term persons to fill these key positions. An eighth important appointment will be that of the executive officer of the Council. The Government should give the closest attention to finding the very best people in Australia to fill these positions and persuading them to serve Australia in these capacities.

The third and final aspect of the report I wish to comment on concerns the school languages which are commended and envisaged as being most available for teaching and learning in Australian schools. Page 125 of the report lists the following languages which are, with very small exception, similar to the list I have advocated at various professional conferences on languages over the last five years: Mandarin Chinese, Indonesian-Malay, Japanese, French, German, Italian, Modern Greek, Arabic and Spanish. The report states:

These combine Australia's external needs and domestic needs in a realistic way. The languages which particularly require promotion from this group, due to presently inadequate resource levels, are: Chinese; Japanese; Indonesian-Malay; Arabic and Spanish, although Italian and Modern Greek warrant some additional attention. In a subsequent period, French and German require bolstering as well.

I believe that is a fair summary of the languages of priority. We need to ensure that there are resourced curricula for their teaching in schools. The Lo Bianco report calls them `languages of wider teaching'. I have no quarrel with that. They are languages of importance to Australia. I make the statement, as have many other honourable senators today in looking at this report, that we need to take stock of the Asian context of our region and the importance to trade and every other aspect of our regional context of ensuring that there are more Australians with a genuine knowledge of Chinese and Japanese, in particular.

Some will quarrel with the fact that there is hardly a mention of Latin in this report. I understand that Latin is still a minority language. However I list those nine, 10 or 11 languages in order of pre-eminence, I am sufficiently grateful for my own experience in Latin-whilst I detested it at the time-to say responsibly that it is still a language of usefulness which should be taught in Australian schools for those who freely opt to take it. It will greatly expand such students' knowledge of English and other languages and will be a key to understanding much of Western history and philosophy. I think that Latin is still a useful language. Indeed, in a few Australian schools some 40 languages, such as Russian, Maltese, Dutch and even Latvian, are being taught. I say `even Latvian' simply because of the small number of families, relative to others, who speak Latvian.

The principle endorsed in the report is the principle of the Senate Standing Committee on Education and the Arts; that is, it is the national responsibility, in league with the States, to ensure that resources are available for the teaching and learning of languages, especially those I mentioned initially. However, it is the responsibility of the school community, on the basis of all the available aspects being considered, to determine the language that that school will adopt as its second language or the languages that it will adopt as its second and third languages. English is of priority. Every Australian, including every school child, must have the best access to English, including methodologies of teaching, such as for teaching English as a second language. I welcome entirely the Lo Bianco report's endorsement that all Australians should have the opportunity to experience the learning of a second language. I would also include, if they wished to do so, the learning of an Aboriginal language.

The Lo Bianco report sets out some 30 recommendations. They are precisely summarised from page 189 onwards and they summarise the findings of part 2 of the report. As far as I can see on a first reading, they are a fair response to the 117 recommendations of the Senate Committee. Whilst I cannot vouch for every one of them at this stage, as I have had only a short time in which to read the report, I can see from everything that I have read to this point that they are a very positive response to the Senate Committee. As I have said, the report of the Senate Committee on national language policy and the Lo Bianco report entitled `National Policy on Languages', which the Government fully endorses, will, I believe, sit together for the next two decades. I hope that the early appointment of the Advisory Council, the considerations of the Government in the preparation of the Budget and the liaison with the States and Territories will achieve the focus for which we have all called.

I conclude by noting that what we speak about on this topic is wider than just a person's ability with a language. The report comes at a time when Australia is quite distinctive in the world in comparison with similar developments in other countries. Nowhere else in the world is there as evident the kind of potential for creative language resources that there is in Australia now and has been in the past five years. Australia has a distinctive approach, as the Government response endorses. What we are considering is the kind of resource that a language resource is. The issue is not just about knowledge; it is about power, power to be a part of Australia. It is also about individual fulfilment. I believe strongly in the Liberal principle of accepting and respecting every individual for who he or she is. The growing self-awareness of every individual, the growth of self-confidence in every individual and the ability to communicate for every individual are also of fundamental importance. I welcome the Government's response to the Senate Committee's report. I look forward to reading the Joe Lo Bianco report in even greater detail.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Macklin Sen M.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —The report entitled `National Policy on Languages' is a very important one. It is probably the best summary that I have seen anywhere of the language as it exists in a country and how that language in all of its forms should be developed in the interests of that country. When we talk about language, we are not talking about just something that most people in the community probably remember as having had forced on them at school; we are talking about the means of communication, not only among ourselves as Australians but also between this country and other countries.

SPEECH.PARA: Language will become increasingly important in the future; for example, as we develop our tourist industry. Tourism requires a range of basic language skills of our citizens. We are not talking about just the aesthetic value of a person having the ability to pick up a book written in some other language and to browse through it for his or her own delectation and amusement; we are talking about a person's ability to converse with people visiting this country in their language, so that they can feel at home and feel that Australia is a useful place of destination for their tourist dollar. We are also talking about the ability of our citizens who travel overseas to speak the languages of other countries and to develop our trade with those countries through basic skills that are a mere courtesy to another country if we want to do trade with it.

When we consider the policy on languages, let it not be thought that we are talking about merely something to go on in schools to fill in the time between 9 a.m. and 3 p.m. We are talking about something which is of fundamental importance to our economy and to a multicultural society as diverse as ours. We know a fair amount, from the literature, about the education needs of children in their native language-their mother tongue, as it is called in the report. We know how very important it is that the first language in which the child is taught be the language of the home and that, progressively, that person comes to learn a majority language, for example, English.

The report indicates that almost half of all Australian students have no experience of studying another language for any period. We are, as a country, excessively proud of English; seemingly more so than the English are, because the situation in Great Britain is far better than that. By an accident of geography we have managed to become monolingual to an extent that no other country, except those which have chosen to cut themselves off from the rest of the world, is. When one looks, for example, at the material provided about school languages-Senator Teague referred to some of those-one sees that about 7 per cent of schools teach French; roughly 5 per cent teach German; 4 per cent teach Italian; 0.8 per cent teach Indonesian which is the first language of our region; 0.6 per cent teach modern Greek; 0.6 per cent teach Japanese-Japan is the country with which we do most of our trade; and 0.58 per cent, a very close runner to Japanese, teach Latin.

I am probably among a number of honourable senators who had inflicted upon them at school Latin, classical Greek and Hebrew, all of which I soon found out were not spoken by anybody in the world; certainly not by anybody with whom we could do any trade. The last lot died out several thousands years ago. When I went to university I studied Japanese, on the grounds that it was the language which surely of all languages Australians ought to study. By saying that I do not by any means seek to denigrate the languages that I did learn at school. I must say that Latin comes in terribly handy when you want to read inscriptions on tombs. In fact, I found it very handy last year to do precisely that. But I am not at all sure that four years spent learning a language for that type of return is really what I would term an efficient use of resources. I am very much of the view that the predominant language which we should be seeking to teach our children in schools is Japanese. The other languages of the region, such as Indonesian, I think are extremely important and will in fact become much more important in the future.

We are blessed in this country with having our basic language as English. It is the language of commerce of the world, the language of aviation of the world, the language of banking of the world and in fact is the dominant language in the world. That makes it pretty easy for us. I shudder to think what would have happened if the French or the Spanish had decided to stay here when they first arrived because, given our propensity not to learn anybody else's language, we would have had a dickens of a time doing any trade with the rest of the world. It so happens that we learnt the right language through no fault of our own. But I think that lulled us into a false sense of security, and unless we improve our game in this area we are going to be in increasing difficulties.

One of the things that I was discussing over the weekend, before I got a serve from the Queensland Premier, is that when we are talking about the use of money which is raised by taxation, we must realise that nobody else in this country is going to fund languages taught by the schools. That teaching is going to be funded out of the taxpayer's pocket. If we do not have the taxpayers for that, all the pious words in the world will do us absolutely no good at all. Nobody in this country has ever shown the slightest interest in trying to teach languages to children, other than the schools of this country, other than the tertiary institutions and other than those institutions which have been funded totally out of the taxpayer's pocket. The only other major language teaching operation in this country is done by the ethnic communities to the people in their own communities as a continuation of their traditions. Yet we find this Government setting its face against that and capping the amount of money going to those ethnic schools, and in the next Budget we will probably see a total winding back of that effort.

Essentially, we have an Opposition which is intent on massively cutting government expenditure, and languages will be an area that will probably go. The Government which is in power is now looking to see where it might cut funding, and of course it is picking on this area as being dispensable. Probably the one major political factor that has emerged in the debate in the last year has been the willingness of the ethnic community to come to the defence of ethnic languages, and hence coincidentally, to come to the defence of some reasonable language policy. If we do see some stabilisation in this area in terms of government funding, it will not be because of the political parties; it will be because of the efforts of those groups in the community which have got out there, campaigned pretty hard and brought home to the people in this place that they had better be careful about the type of operation they engage in when it comes to languages.

There are some startling facts and figures in this report. I hope quite a number of people in the community will see fit to get a copy of it and read it. In its discussion of Aboriginal languages it points out that we are losing one Aboriginal language a year. It has got to the stage where one Aboriginal language a year is no longer used as a viable language and to all intents and purposes it becomes extinct. That is appalling, and hence it shows again the need to move, and to move rapidly, to get some resources, particularly so the linguistic anthropologists will be able to categorise and work with those languages and to systematise the transliteration of them. Where there are pockets of speakers we would thus have the ability to achieve some continuation of that language in terms of teaching and written material.

The proposition that this report contains for moving beyond the current situation are, I agree with Senator Teague, conservative. That is one of the values of this report. One could go overboard and suggest all sorts of wonderful things that could be done in any area. Obviously, the practical constraints of expenditure do not allow that. One of the useful things of this report I think is that it is couched in terms that could be met, and I hope will be met, in the Budget this year. I am particularly interested in the proposal for the Australian second language learning program. I think it is a very sensible program, one which, in terms of the costings done in the report, is suggested in 1987-88 to cost $7.5m. I hope this Government will see it-now that it has this material and it has given such praise to this report-as a necessity to find some space within the education budget for this proposition.

I am hopeful that the continuing funding in years to come-the $7.5m each year over the next triennium-will be fulfilled by whatever government comes in after the next election, whether it be an Australian Labor Party Government delivering the 1988-89 Budget, or whatever other lot is in power next year.

TALK.START.PARA: —Liberal.

—A Liberal government, say the Liberals, and since Senator Bjelke- Petersen is reading some other material at the moment, presumably she is not going to say a National Party government. Whether it be a Liberal Party led conservative government or a National Party led conservative government, I hope it will find the $7.5m that is required for the 1988 and 1989 Budgets. It is important that that particular proposal be extended. Some of the other areas unfortunately are not costed, and I know it is relatively difficult to cost these. Given the amount of time that the author of the report had, I am not seeking to blame him in any way for that. But the area of teacher education is one that I think is also very important. I am a great supporter of the notion that teacher education in this area is best done in the country where the language is spoken. That is a much more expensive proposition.

SPEECH.PARA: I am reminded of that program on the teaching of French which appears on the Special Broadcasting Service at about 8.15 p.m. It starts off with the very salutary point-it is a British Broadcasting Corporation program-that O level French in fact is a language which is not spoken in France; that O level French is a language which is spoken only in English schools and not by anybody else on earth. A lot of our language training in this country unfortunately falls into that category. If we asked a few people around here to venture a few words in the languages that they laboured over at school or university, I think we would find exactly the same type of thing, whether it be Italian, Indonesian or whatever other language. I believe that is a travesty.

I am reminded of the fact that the Expo pamphlet which was produced at a great cost and taken over to France was, in fact, shredded. Once the people in the Embassy had read it, they were so appalled by it that they had to shred it before it was circulated because it was worthwhile only for stuffing pillows, or whatever is done with shredded paper. It certainly was not worth giving to people who actually speak French. It is appalling that we should have such bad translations going out of this country. It reminds me of some of the material we receive with watches which purports to tell us how to get our watches working in something which is ostensibly English but which in fact is probably much closer to the original Japanese. That is not good enough.

I believe that a waste of money in this area is worse than anything. We have only small resources so let us put them in the area where we can do some good. If we are to have reasonable language teaching, we have to put resources into teachers. I am terribly sorry to keep harping on that point, as I do in every education debate. It is all very well to say that we have high technology coming along and that we should do something about it in the schools. I remind honourable senators that the only way to do anything about it in the schools is to do something with the teachers first, and that costs money. Teachers should not only have pre-service training in a language in the country of its origin, but also they should have regular, professional updating. Again, that would require a sojourn to those countries at least once every five years to upgrade their capacity, their accent and their understanding of the language in the country of origin. If we think we can get away with it on the cheap, we will. No one will actually drop dead if a teacher gets the wrong pronunciation, but its usefulness for Australia and for the things that I mentioned at the beginning of my speech-trade, the economy and tourism-will be diminished.

Another area, and the last area to which I want to refer, is adult illiteracy. It is all very well to talk about the need to develop our language skills and their usefulness to our economy but we already have a massive literacy problem in this country. It is estimated that well over one million adult Australians cannot read their own names. I am not referring to people of ethnic origin, I am referring to people born and raised to speak English who cannot read their own names. That is extraordinary when one thinks about the loss of productivity to this country, but it is even more extraordinary when one thinks of the loss to those individuals; what we are doing to them; what they suffer in their own lives; and how their families suffer as a result. On any count, resources put into the massive problem of adult illiteracy in Australia would be money well spent. This has been pointed out in the report; the matter has been raised; the magnitude of the problem has been debated; and the various efforts of State departments have been alluded to.

When we look at the paucity of resources going to this massive problem and at the work being done in this area, basically by volunteers-hundreds, probably thousands, of Australians give up their time on an unpaid basis to work on a one to one relationship with other people who cannot read or write English-we realise that we are being propped up in this area by a tremendous effort on the part of these Australians. But that effort is not enough and cannot be enough. The resources going to them for material is pitiable. The backup that those people get is non-existent, so they get burnt out and we lose them from that particular effort. It is a pity. With some backup and resources I am quite sure that those people would continue with their voluntary job and, thereby, would be able to give so much more to the community in terms of getting at least one more Australian to read and write and, hence, to develop directly his skills and, indirectly, the economy.

At the end of the day a national policy on language is only as good as the resources that are made available to move that policy ahead. Presumably, the Government is studying this issue closely. We will see the outcome of that deliberation in August. I hope we will see resources made available to get this program under way and a continuing commitment to increase those resources at the levels necessary to make it viable and profitable. Without that this report will go the way of report of the Senate Standing Committee on Education and the Arts. It will be the best up to date, on the shelf report that we have on this issue to be gazed at and quoted from in speeches made by Ministers for Education, but there will be no action in the community where it matters.

I hope that the Government will commence the implementation of this report. The Australian Democrats will strongly support it in any such moves. I am reminded of the fact that when Senator Chipp was elected in 1977, almost 10 years ago, in one of his speeches he raised the vital necessity of having a national language policy for Australia. We have been urging, supporting and arguing for such a policy ever since. We have here an excellent blueprint for such a policy. It is now up to the Government to take forward into action the work that has been done over so many years by so many people, including the excellent report produced by the Senate Committee five years ago and this report. The next step has to be action on Budget night when the people who have spoken in this debate and many others in the community will be reading the fine print to see what will actually happen.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Bjelke-Petersen Sen F.I.

TALK.START.PARA: —As the National Party spokesman on education I rise to speak briefly on the report entitled the `National Policy on Languages', which is the Government's response to the report of the Senate Standing Committee on Edu- cation and the Arts entitled `A National Language Policy'. With other speakers I agree that the Government's response is conservative. The Minister for Education (Senator Ryan) made a statement, as follows:

SPEECH.PARA: National policy on languages starts from the premise that English is the national language. The report examines in detail ways to improve the teaching of English and to ensure that all groups in the community have effective command of the English language, including adults who need literacy programs. This reiteration of the basic importance of proper teaching and learning of English is welcomed and endorsed by the Government.

That seems to me to be one of the very important elements in this report; namely, that the literacy rates of ordinary Australians are bad and that they have fallen. I accept the fact that it is the responsibility of the schools and the State governments to teach the children, but I do not believe that they are being taught the skills to allow them to express themselves properly and this, perhaps, is the basis of some of the problems. Page 195 of the report states:
It is proposed that a concerted and well-planned campaign be implemented during 1988 to attempt to improve levels of adult literacy.

I sometimes wonder whether the reading by looking scheme that was introduced to the education of our children some years ago has been helpful. It is amazing that some children can go through 10 years or more of school and yet be barely literate. I commend, as does Senator Macklin, the volunteers who help people with literacy problems. It is very hard to realise that over a million Australians cannot read or write their own names. They certainly need help in this regard.

It is a long time since I was at school, but in those days grammar and spelling were so important. I like to think that I can spell well. I do not know whether honourable senators will agree with me when I say that I am literate. They might not agree with me at all.

TALK.START.PARA: —Don't tempt me!
—Thank you. I hope the honourable senator was saying nice things. If one does not have proper training--
—Isn't this a reflection of what is happening in Queensland, as well as the rest of Australia?

—I think it is something that needs to be looked at by the departments of education in every State. This problem does not occur just in Queensland. If Senator Watson went around the schools in Tasmania he would find that the same problems exist there. I am not holding it up as something peculiar to Queensland. I am trying to explain to the Senate in my own works why I think we have some of these problems. I do not know whether the school my daughter teaches at gives students spelling lists, but I know that the school my granddaughter attends does so. It is very important that children know how to spell. One must learn the basics. If one does not know the basics, it is a bit like being asked to play a Beethoven concerto when one has not learnt to play the scales. Another illustration would be asking someone who has not done the necessary training to run a four-minute mile. It is important that all teachers in all schools teach the basic skills and help children to express themselves, to write and to spell properly. I believe that all of those things are very important for good communication. One theory suggests that it is all right for children to spell phonetically, that they should be allowed to write stories spelling words the way the words sound. That is the way many young people write words. I had a letter the other day from a nice young man. The letter was certainly written phonetically.

SPEECH.PARA: A section in the report deals with English as a second language for migrants and Aborigines. English should be taught to migrants, for it is the language they have to speak and deal with in their everyday lives. They have come to Australia to live and to work, and English is Australia's basic language. There is a great need for migrants and Aborigines to be able to speak English. If I went to Germany to live, I believe I would have to learn German because I would not expect other people to accommodate me if I could speak only English. I learnt French at high school, but when I visited the European Parliament a couple of years ago I found that I was unable to speak French, mainly because, I suppose, I had not been using it and I had forgotten what I had learnt at school all those years ago.

The States are already working to ensure that the Aboriginal languages are being protected from extinction. The report says that it is intended to supplement funding of State and Territory governments by another $6m over a period of three years to ensure that Aboriginal languages do not die out. That is also important.
There is a section in the report that deals with other languages. Page 26 of the report deals with languages other than English that are being taught in schools. It states:

Only 17.3 per cent of all school students study one or more languages other than English at any one time. Fewer than one third of all Australian schools teach one or more languages other than English. Only 10 per cent of primary schools teach any language other than English. 15 per cent of all secondary schools do not teach any language other than English.

I learnt French and Latin at high school. Senator Macklin and Senator Teague mentioned Latin in this debate. I must say that I liked Latin when I was at school. I do not know whether my teacher would have said that I was brilliant, but I was very disappointed when I did not get an A for Latin in my junior, because I liked it and I worked hard at it. Latin helps students with grammar, with parsing and in understanding how words are formed. It is important, but it seems to be dying out. I used to think that it was part of the universal language. Doctors used to use Latin when they wrote prescriptions. Now they write English, but what they write is nearly as bad as Latin because one can never read what they write.

I have to question the wisdom of establishing the huge network of committees outlined in this national policy on languages, whose purpose will be to achieve the aims stated, such as promoting better literacy, and Australian students learning a second language. I have no argument with this, but I wonder whether it is necessary to have such an enormous number of committees when we are always talking about less government. We should be thinking about reducing bureaucracy, not increasing it. The real challenge will be to find an easy way to do this without spending a lot of money.

I draw the Senate's attention to the fact that 20 years ago 40 per cent of secondary students learnt a second language. Today, only about 12 per cent do. Twenty years ago literacy rates were better. Do we need all these committees that will cost money to return to the better standards that we had 20 years ago? I do not believe so. I have been very interested to read Mr Joseph Lo Bianco's report on the national policy on languages and I am glad to know that the Government has made this response to the Senate Committee's original report.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Vigor Sen D.B.

TALK.START.PARA: —The report on a national policy on languages by Joseph Lo Bianco is indeed a significant document. However, it comes in the wake of the devastation caused by the Government cuts to English as a second language funding and its abolition of the multicultural education program in last year's Budget. This leads me to ask whether the fine words of the report will be translated into action. It will require much more than fine words from the Prime Minister (Mr Hawke), the Minister for Education (Senator Ryan) and the Minister for Immigration and Ethnic Affairs (Mr Young) to set in place a properly constituted national language strategy. The development of community languages is, I believe, an extremely important part of the program proposed here and proposed by the previous Senate Standing Committee on Education and the Arts, and forms part of our national infrastructure. As a matter of priority, we must ensure that we develop a language program which will teach Australians to speak the languages of the communities in which they live. In many cases that is not always English.

SPEECH.PARA: On page 189 of the report are listed the language problems which any policy must address, and I would like to remind the Senate of these. The problems include: Overcoming injustice, disadvantages and discrimination related to language; the enrichment of cultural and intellectual life within Australia; the integration of language teaching and learning with Australia's external economic and political needs and priorities; and the provision of clear expectations to the community about language in general and about language in education in particular. We also face the problem of supporting the component groups of Australian society-our ethnic communities, the deaf and the Aboriginal groups-for whom language issues are extremely important, with recognition, encouragement and guidance. We should also use every possible technology and language learning facility which can be made available.
On page 120 the `National Policy on Languages' report indicates:

Almost half of all Australian school students never study a language other than English at any time during their schooling. Fewer than 12 per cent of students matriculate with a language other than English.

Indeed, I am pleased to say that in South Australia we have a slightly better situation than is the case in Australia as a whole. My children attend Adelaide High School, which is a special language high school. They have the opportunity, and have taken up that opportunity, to study two or more languages during the course of their studies. However, the matriculation system does not allow them to carry this through for examination purposes.

In May 1985 South Australia announced a 10-year program for the development of language teaching. Its aim was to get each child in primary and secondary school exposed to another language; to establish co-ordinating networks; and to establish after hours South Australian secondary school of languages teaching facilities. Indeed, a number of communities as well as the Education Department itself have developed Saturday schools. The German community, the Polish community and a number of Slavonic communities in Adelaide have developed such schools. I know that they also exist in New South Wales and Canberra. The establishment of a centre for multicultural studies at Flinders University has, I believe, been a major advance in trying to integrate our language in South Australia. The consideration of a centre of excellence and tertiary institute of languages at that university would be, I believe, a very fitting part of any national language program development within my own State.

The South Australian Government has also maintained the Multicultural Education Co-ordinating Committee despite the closure of the Commonwealth's multicultural education program. It is unfortunate that the Commonwealth program closed down because this has resulted in the loss of a large number of resources and teaching positions throughout Australia. In South Australia the Government threw in some of its own resources, but this has not been the case in some other States. In New South Wales, in the Marrickville Council area alone 15 teaching positions have been lost as a result of the end of the multicultural education program, and a variety of resource centres have been closed down. It is very important that we have the right material available for teaching language and for holding the cultural message associated with language.

In New South Wales, 20 community liaison officers have lost their jobs in the metropolitan areas and 15 have lost their jobs in country areas. Activities under the ethnic aides program have been curtailed and the community outreach effort has been eroded as a result. The Commonwealth's commitment to a national language strategy is essential, but a national policy alone will not reverse the damage that has been done by the dismantling of the multicultural education program and all of its associated aids. The multicultural education program served a much wider purpose than just the teaching of language. The text books and materials were used in a much wider context than just in the individual language courses. It is very important that we do not lose these resources and that we develop language teaching material suitable to Australian conditions.

I must remind the Senate that Australia is the second most diverse society in the world after Israel in terms of the number of places where our citizens have been born. Many people have learnt other languages to start off with. This report tells us some of that story. We must not lose that resource because those people and their knowledge of language and their knowledge of the cultures of the various parts of the world that they came from are an important resource to Australian trade. We must not allow that expertise to be dissipated and frittered away. We must encourage parents to teach their children the cultural values of the countries from which they may have come. We must integrate and weave each one of these cultural habits and each one of these language habits into the Australian way of life. If we lose the opportunities of keeping up those language skills amongst our citizens and if we lose the opportunities to create wealth for Australia by having these people who can actually talk, trade and operate effectively in the world, we will lose a significant wealth creating capacity for Australia. I refer to a significant quote attributed to a German trade Minister on page 53 of the report: The Minister said:
If you wish to buy from us, there is no need to speak German. But if you wish to sell to us . . . that is a different matter.

I believe that to be a trading nation in a trading world, to be an effective partner in international affairs and to be able to stand proudly as an Australian nation, we should aim at having most of our citizens bilingual at least.

I would like to commend Mr Lo Bianco for the manner in which he has undertaken his task. He has thrown an enormous amount of energy into his work. I have some reservations only about some of the languages in the wider teaching languages section because I believe that by concentrating on specific languages for which we have teaching skills in our schools we may end up losing a lot of the resource. I was particularly disappointed to see that there were no Slavonic languages on the list of languages which are available. I believe that we should make certain that we target all of the significant ethnic groups within our community and make certain that their languages and cultures continue to be part of the Australian multicultural society. This will be the only way in which we can develop a strong, independent multicultural Australia.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Baume Sen M.E.

TALK.START.PARA: —We are debating tonight the report by Joseph Lo Bianco, `National Policy on Languages'. We have had some interesting speeches so far which have outlined the basic problems that we are having in coping with the special relationship that Australians and the Australian education system should have with foreign languages. I wish to deal with a particular element of this report, that section relating to trade. It is evident from this report by Mr Lo Bianco that this is an area of considerable concern. In the report he notes that the languages of key trading partners are under represented in the teaching programs of Australian schools and that very few subjects are offered in the languages of our South Pacific neighbours. Despite the growing numbers of Japanese tourists coming to Australia, for example, few employees in the tourist industry have any familiarity with Japanese. Of course, Australia's economic future will significantly depend on the extent to which, conscious of the cultural differences between our nations, we can communicate with other people in their own languages.

SPEECH.PARA: This report deals with this specifically in some detail. I shall quote some extracts from the report and then refer to the extent to which there has been a monumental failure to address those problems. The report points out on page 48 that it is the conviction of other major English speaking nations, such as the United States of America, that they have forgone demonstrable economic opportunities in external trade due to inadequate and inappropriate language teaching policies domestically. I stress that the lack of adequate and appropriate language teaching policies domestically has had a disadvantageous economic impact on the United States. That has been acknowledged and one presumes that the United States, having recognised that disadvantage, has done something about it. I wonder to what extent this Government intends to seek to influence the education systems of the States-let us face it, the Government has a cash involvement with the States-to remedy this situation which appears to be approaching disaster level. I go back to the report. It says:

In general terms, all Australians conducting business in non-English-speaking countries or who are involved in formal and informal arrangements between Australia and such countries will be greatly advantaged by having language skills and cultural knowledge appropriate to their task. There are many instances where this is indispensable.
We have a clear statement in the report dramatising the significance and the importance of foreign languages, particularly in trading in our region. The report goes on:

There is substantial evidence that Australian economic activities, particularly in competitive situations requiring market penetration, would benefit from the skilled use of the host country's languages and active knowledge and appreciation of cultural values and behaviours. This can be a determining factor in gaining a competitive advantage in trade. In situations of intense competition for markets and considering the particularly trade-dependent nature of Australia's economy, it is important to harmonise national economic strategies with the goals of languages policy. Australia's total trade with non-English-speaking countries greatly exceeds its trading volumes with English-speaking countries.
The report continues:

This shift which has occurred over the last two decades has coincided with a general reduction in second-language learning and teaching in Australia. In addition the languages of the key trading partners are particularly poorly represented in Australia's schooling system.

This is a major indictment of the language policies of the education system throughout Australia. I am unaware of any effort by this Government to improve this disastrous situation. On the contrary, not only has there been nothing done to improve this disastrous situation but also the figures underline the fact that since the magic date of 1983, when this Government was elected, the situation has massively deteriorated. Page 28 of the report reveals that the number of students presenting Chinese, for example, at matriculation level has collapsed from the 1,043 of 1983 to only 794 in 1986. Under this Government, with its failure to address this issue, there has been a massive fall in the number of people prepared to take this course of study for the leaving certificate, matriculation or the equivalent educational standard in each State. Yet we are told consistently by this Government that there is a special need for us to address the question of the Chinese market and that we must be aware of the great opportunities that exist there. However, nothing is being done to encourage the learning of this language; on the contrary, the numbers are significantly deteriorating. We have the same situation with the study of Indonesian. The peak year in that case was also 1983, when 1,542 students around Australia undertook matriculation Indonesian. This figure has almost halved to 819 students. What is going wrong?

TALK.START.PARA: —Good question.

—I thank Senator Kilgariff. I think it is a question that this Government should answer. It is about time it did. It took something like six months for this Government to respond to this report. In the response of the Minister for Education (Senator Ryan) there is no adequate or coherent answer to these matters of major moment. Let us look at the study of Malaysian. Three years ago there were 587 students doing matriculation level Malaysian. This figure is now down to 149 students, less than one-third of the number of three years ago. I repeat my question: What is going wrong? What is the Government doing about it? I guess the Government would suggest that at least in the area of Japanese studies there has been an increase. That is true. The only area where there is an increase in the number of students taking the language of one of our trading neighbours and political associates in our region is--
—A very important neighbour and relationship in our area.

I go back to the report which states:

Invariably Australia's trading efforts depend either on the provision of interpreters, usually not Australians, or on the use of English by Australia's trading partners. Dependence on interpreters, though often inevitable and necessary, can be cumbersome and restrictive. One is always reminded of descriptions of the ugly Americans or the ugly Australians who appear to be unable to conduct themselves in a way appropriate to the standards of behaviour in other countries, particularly Asian. The report continues:

In addition, predictions about the nature, level of demand, range, and manner of promoting particular products will be greatly improved if cultural and linguistic knowledge of the societies with whom Australia wishes to trade or wishes to improve existing terms of trade are better understood.

These economic considerations create a demand and a significant unmet need for language learning of a particular type in Australia. A number of specific vocational opportunities flow from these considerations. They include the training of interpreters and translators in demand languages, and greatly increased teaching of the languages of Australia's key trading partners and the languages of the non-English-speaking countries which it is possible to predict Australia's economic relations will require in the future. There is, concomitantly, a need for the development of courses specifically designed for the purposes of economic affairs focusing on the development of communicative skills in relative business and trade-related contexts. However, general language skills and cultural knowledge need also to be incorporated.

This report clearly states what is needed and exactly the opposite is taking place under the education policies and programs administered by this Government and by the State governments with which it is associated in the provision of education. It is all very well for the Government to say: `We simply provide the money'. There is within that general duty a responsibility to encourage the States-it is a responsibility outlined in this report-to take a position which is certainly different from this disastrous trend outlined of a significant reduction in the number of students now undertaking study of these vital languages. As I said earlier, I concede that some States do better than others. But it is nonetheless a disturbing pattern and one which is of major disadvantage to us. In many instances Australians are now well regarded in Asia as having made some effort. But overall I have to say that we are seen as arrogant and insensitive in expecting the people with whom we trade to speak English. A German trade Minister is quoted in the report as saying:
If you wish to buy from us, there is no need to speak German. But if you wish to sell to us . . .

Of course, that is the important issue. We are endeavouring to sell to our region. We are facing economic disaster because of our inability to sell overseas adequately and because of our enthusiastic importing far in excess of our ability to sell. I want to encourage the Government to take far greater note of this report in this area than I expect it will do, and far greater note of it than previous speakers have forecast that the Government will do.

As Senator Teague has said, there is no doubt that the Opposition welcomes this report. It is an important contribution to the cause of further developing language skills in Australia. But this strategy-I have just demonstrated how important the strategy is in economic terms-rests entirely on the Government's willingness to make available the money for this program, not necessarily by increasing in large volumes the amount of money available but by reorganising its expenditure priorities. This Government appears to have no coherent expenditure priorities in this area. We have seen what has happened with the massive reduction in the number of students undertaking the sorts of studies that are essential for our trading activities. The drastic cuts this year to the English as a second language programs, to ethnic schools and to multicultural education programs all seem to indicate an insensitivity to the language needs of many in our community. There is clearly an insensitivity on the Government's part to the language needs of those who will be dealing with and trading with people overseas.

The reduced funding to the professional development program and the cessation of funding for many education centres will make it even more difficult to promote improved teaching capacity in languages no matter how essential that is to our economic future and no matter how much a cost-benefit analysis demonstrates the total advantage to us. It is essential that all Australians have access to language training so that they may not only develop high levels of proficiency in English but also have the opportunity to develop talents in community and foreign languages.

Senator Teague was a major contributor to that report and he played a significant role in it. This Government is so concerned with the figures that I have just demonstrated, indicating a massive fall-off in education in those languages of such economic concern to us, that it has taken it three years to respond to that report. As I mentioned earlier, Mr Lo Bianco's report has been in the hands of the Minister since 28 November last year. It has taken six months for the Government to get around to considering its findings.

Let me add that the Budget decisions last year significantly reduced the language effort in Australia and have thrown administration and planning of language programs into great confusion. The Opposition is concerned that the report makes no specific financial recommendations for the English as a second language program and seems to sanction the phasing out of the ESL general support element. But there is no doubt that the report has correctly identified the importance of language skills in Australia's trade relations and, of course, in the tourism industry. DEBATE.SUB1.TITLE: Report on Administration of Property Functions

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Watson Sen J.O.W.

TALK.START.PARA: —I present the 272nd report of the Joint Committee of Public Accounts entitled `Administration of the Commonwealth's Property Functions'. I seek leave to make a short statement.

SPEECH.PARA: Leave granted.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Public Accounts Committee decided to undertake a wide-ranging inquiry into the administration of Commonwealth property in 1984 after consideration of a report of the Auditor-General. At that time the audit report was the latest in a succession of reports which indicated that there were continuing problems with the Commonwealth's property administration. This was despite the creation of the Property Directorate in 1980 within the Department of Local Government and Administrative Services.

SPEECH.PARA: Subsequent to the commencement of the Committee's inquiry-in July 1986-an inter-departmental review of the property functions was announced by the Government. The review, chaired by the Public Service Board, was to report earlier this year. The Committee has programmed its activities to ensure that its recommendations are available in a timely fashion to the Government in its consideration of the Public Service Board's more detailed review. The aims of this inquiry were to find out whether there were major fundamental problems in the delivery of the Commonwealth's property functions, to identify their causes and to determine the reasons for their persistence. A final aim was to assess whether there were workable alternative administrative structures which, if implemented, could lead to demonstrable improvements.

The current inquiry was therefore necessarily broad in scope and focused on aspects of the domestic property function. The Committee received over 60 submissions from 45 organisations, representing Commonwealth agencies, unions and non-government organisations, including some with large property portfolios. Eight public hearings were held and the Committee visited Perth, Sydney and Canberra locations for inspections. The large number of organisations participating in the inquiry and the level of their representation at the Committee's hearings suggested that there were widespread concerns about the delivery of the Commonwealth's property functions. The overwhelming theme of the evidence received was that the existing administrative arrangements were cumbersome, slow and inflexible and that major changes were necessary.

In general, the Committee concluded that the central problem with property administration appeared to be the complex and cumbersome procedures which had evolved as a result of the involvement of too many disparate organisations with overlapping areas of responsibility. This served to perpetuate and exacerbate the delays in the delivery of property services. Further problems have arisen both from the difficulties inherent in the Budget process and from a lack of planning on the part of client departments. The Committee is of the view that strategic control by a central co-ordinating body is necessary for the efficient functioning of property administration. However, allied to the retention of the central body is the streamlining of procedures, the precise determination of areas of responsibility and the devolution of financial responsibility and many of the more routine functions to clients.

The Committee feels that the central co-ordinating role currently performed by DOLGAS should continue to be the responsibility of that portfolio, with a Central Property Agency performing such a role where property matters are concerned. The Committee has therefore recommended that a Central Property Agency be the central body responsible for the administration of the Commonwealth's property functions, with overall policy control. The Central Property Agency should be established as an independent, ministerially accountable agency with responsibility for the management of the Commonwealth-owned estate.

The Central Property Agency would retain strategic control for the following purposes: To advise on strategic planning; to protect the national interest, particularly in the case of disposals; to prevent gazumping; to develop and implement strategies on the location of Commonwealth Government employment, particularly in the major cities; and to ensure a co-operative relationship with other levels of government. The Central Property Agency would have responsibility for the following strategic functions: The provision of policy advice to the Minister; the management of owned property; compulsory acquisitions under the Lands Acquisition Act; the forecasting of future property requirements; the rationalisation of the Commonwealth's property portfolio; the setting of accommodation guidelines; and finally the collection of aggregate information, providing a central point for information on the Commonwealth's property holdings.

As a complement to the Central Property Agency, the Committee feels that there is a case for the devolution of certain routine functions to clients. The Committee further proposes that full financial responsibility, including Budget sponsorship for property programs, be devolved to clients. Because the costs of accommodation and associated property services for each agency form part of the overheads associated with program delivery, decisions on resource allocation at the department or authority level are best decided in the context of the department's or authority's own budget. As part of the rationalisation of responsibilities, the Committee has further recommended that all construction and fit out activity above the tender threshold be the sole responsibility of the Department of Housing and Construction.

The Committee's other major recommendations include: Responsibility for routine servicing functions to be devolved to departments and authorities; the option of using outside expertise for such services; the establishment of a Property Advisory Board; the institution of trust account funding arrangements; the development by the Central Property Agency of an efficient management information system and performance indicators; the implementation of a career structure for property specialists within the Australian Public Service; the creation of a separate item within departmental and non-trading statutory authority appropriations to provide for excess maintenance and restoration costs associated with Commonwealth properties listed on the Register of the National Estate; the delegation of the Minister's powers under the Lands Acquisition Act to off-Budget statutory authorities, with the proviso that there be mandatory compliance by such authorities within ministerial directions in order to give effect to the strategic controls and functions of the Central Property Agency; and finally the approval by the Central Property Agency of disposals on behalf of these off-Budget authorities.

As Deputy Chairman of the Joint Committee of Public Accounts, I commend this report to honourable senators. In so doing, I would like to acknowledge the valuable and important work of the secretariat. I believe that, implemented, these proposals could make far-reaching reforms in the delivery of property services by the Commonwealth and make for a much more efficient organisation.
