The speech read as follows-
This Bill contains measures to streamline the Social Security Act and its administration. These include-
Renumbering the provisions of the Act so that it reads sequentially;
Including current reciprocal agreements on social security with the United Kingdom and with New Zealand in Schedules to the Act;
Ensuring that the basis for prosecution of offences under the Act and the level of penalties are comparable to other Commonwealth offences in legislation;
Requiring that all administrative decisions are to be in writing unless the decisions are recorded on a computer;
Extending the secrecy provision to bind officials who have access to confidential information but who do not have duties or functions under the Act; and
Extending the review and appeal provisions to all decisions made under the provisions under the Act; and
Extending the review and appeal provisions to all decisions made under the provisions of the Act.
Improving the style and format of the legislation

The Social Security Act is amended regularly to put Budget decisions into effect. As a result numbering of sections goes awry. Provisions are difficult to cite. As a step towards improving the legislation, this Bill provides for the renumbering of the Principal Act. Part, Division, section and paragraph numbers will now follow sequentially.
For those accustomed to the previous numbering system, a conversion chart is provided in the Explanatory Memorandum accompanying the Bill to illustrate the changes.
Changes have also been made to some sections to achieve greater clarity of expression.

In addition, Australia has recently concluded an amendment to the reciprocal agreement on social security with the United Kingdom and has entered into a new reciprocal agreement on social security with New Zealand. Rather than being left in Schedules to Regulations, these agreements will be placed in Schedules to the Act for greater ease of access.
The Bill contains minor amendments made necessary by the changes to education allowances.
Offences under the Act

As Honourable Senators will be aware, the Government has taken initiatives to ensure that social security expenditure is limited to those who are eligible under the Act. Measures have also been taken to reduce the level of overpayments. This includes initiatives to limit fraud and to detect and prosecute those who abuse the system.

Section 138 of the Principal Act creates a number of offences where pensions, benefits or allowances are sought by those who are ineligible. This section does not punish innocent mistakes. It lists the basis on which a fraud charge may be brought. As knowledge or recklessness is a necessary component of this type of criminal offence, these words are to be added to the section to reflect the interpretation of the section by the High Court in 1980 in Cameron v Holt. These changes do not affect current practice relating to prosecutions.
The Bill also establishes the basis on which a corporation may be made culpable of an offence under the Act. This takes up provisions in other Commonwealth legislation.

The limits on the time for bringing a prosecution will be removed from the Act. The Director of Public Prosecutions who is primarily responsible for the conduct of social security prosecutions under Commonwealth law should decide on a case by case basis whether the offence is too stale to prosecute successfully. This section in the Principal Act, in any event, can be circumvented by resort to the Crimes Act 1914. This provision, therefore, is a rationalisation of existing practice.

While determined to limit fraud, the Government is concerned to protect the rights and privacy of people who receive social security payments. The Department necessarily collects considerable personal information about the financial and domestic circumstances of claimants in order to assess continuing eligibility. The privacy of these individuals should not be abused.

Section 17 of the Principal Act places an obligation on officers not to divulge personal information obtained in the course of their duties. This section will be extended in line with the secrecy provisions in other Commonwealth legislation such as the Income Tax Assessment Act. Reference to ``officers'' will include former officers as well as others performing work for the Commonwealth who as a result acquire information concerning a person.

An offence under section 17 is treated as a grave matter. The current penalties in the Act are a $5,000 fine or 2 years imprisonment where the offence proceeds on indictment. In the case of summary proceedings, the penalty is $1,000 or imprisonment for 6 months. The Bill would permit both a fine and a period of imprisonment to be imposed. This reflects the seriousness with which such breaches of personal privacy are regarded by this Government.

Penalties are to be increased for other offences under the Act. For failure to comply with the requirements to report circumstances or events which affect entitlement to a social security payment, the penalty will be increased from a $500 fine to a $1,000 fine or six months imprisonment, or both, and a $5,000 fine in the case of corporations.

For failure to comply with a requirement to provide information about entitlement, the fine will be increased from $1,000 and six months imprisonment to $2,000 or 12 months imprisonment, or both, and $10,000 in the case of corporations.
Where financial institutions do not comply with a requirement under the direct deposit provisions, the fine has been increased from $1,000 to $10,000.
Serious breaches of these offences may now be dealt with by suitable sanctions.
Miscellaneous amendments
Finally, the Bill contains amendments to remove anomalies, close gaps, correct minor drafting errors and bring the legislation into line with sound administrative practice.

For example, the definition of a ``decision'' under the Act which is significant from an administrative law point of view as the basis for review or appeal will be amended to confer the same meaning as in the Administrative Appeals Tribunal Act 1975.

It is good administrative practice that decisions of officers affecting entitlements be in writing. This Bill makes it a uniform requirement that all such decisions be in writing. The Department of Social Security is moving to on-line benefits processing-using the latest computer technology to record information and make decisions. This will substantially improve delivery of benefits to those needing assistance. To keep pace with these changes, decisions of officers which are required to be in writing will be deemed to be in writing if originally entered into a computer or recorded with the use of a computer. This processing also enables a printed copy of the decision to be made available to applicants.

By means of these measures which rationalise and simplify the Principal Act this Bill also prepares the ground for substantive reforms to the system of income security when the Government takes decisions on the social security system following the Social Security Review.
I commend the Bill to the Senate.
Debate (on motion by Senator Kilgariff) adjourned.

DEBATE.TITLE: NORTHERN PRAWN FISHERY (SPECIAL PROVISIONS) MANAGEMENT PLAN

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Boswell Sen R.L.D.

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

SPEECH.PARA: That paragraphs 6.1, 9.1 to 9.5, 10.1 to 10.3, 12, 14.1, 14.2 and Schedule 1 of the Northern Prawn Fishery (Special Provisions) Management Plan, as contained in Plan of Management No. 12 of 19 January 1987 and made under the Fisheries Act 1952, be disallowed.

This disallowance motion seeks to delete part of a plan to restructure the northern prawn fishery. It specifically seeks to disallow a situation where property is to be surrendered without compensation and without the right of appeal against that seizure. This, as I will outline to the Senate, is the basic reason why this regulation must be disallowed. It is contrary to the normal standards of justice, equity and fairness that we respect in this country.

The northern prawn fishery covers an area between Cape York in north Queensland and Koolan Island in Western Australia. It is an industry which has developed through sheer hard work and intrepid pioneering spirit. Northern Australia is one of the most uninhabited and hostile environments in the world, yet despite this the industry, which started in the mid-1960s, has prospered and developed, making a very significant contribution to our national economy. Latest figures put the value of the annual catch from the trawler's at $150m. Most of the catch is exported to Japan, bringing in very valuable foreign currency worth over $200m a year.

The major species caught and processed are the banana, tiger, endeavour and king prawns. The industry is administered jointly by the Commonwealth, Queensland, Northern Territory and Western Australia governments. There is an advisory body consisting of fishing trawler owners, processors, State and Federal representatives from the Department of Primary Industry and the Commonwealth Scientific and Industrial Research Organisation. The body is known as the Northern Prawn Fishery Management Advisory Committee or NORMAC.

Since 1976, entry to the fishing area has been limited by the Federal Government. Currently the fleet working in the northern prawn fishery consists of about 230 vessels. While some large companies operate over 10 vessels, most licence holders are individual operators owning only one boat. Many of them are small family businesses which have taken on extensive debts to remain viable in what is a very competitive industry. They are normal people-families who have been fishing the Top End for three or more generations. It is these people, rather than the large companies, who stand to lose the most under the compulsory surrender provisions of the scheme that I am seeking to disallow.

In the last few years the very serious problem of over exploitation of prawn stocks has been identified. I know that the CSIRO has done, and is continuing to do, a lot of work in the area. The industry is aware of the problem and it has also been taking steps and making suggestions on how to reduce the pressure on stocks in the northern prawn fishery. This is despite there being no definite concrete evidence that the fishery is in imminent danger of collapse. Prawns are a renewable resource and they have a relatively short life cycle, about two years. Despite the continuing research by CSIRO and other scientific bodies into them, there is still a lot of uncertainty about their breeding patterns, habits and movements.

The last five years have been abnormally dry in northern Australia. This has had an adverse effect on prawn stocks, as they depend on the flood run off from the rivers and on matter carried into the ocean from the Gulf rivers to provide food. As well, data from the last prawn catch is not yet available. This is because the Australian Fisheries Service has not yet processed it after the fishermen were diligent and co-operative enough to fill out their log books. Yet, despite this uncertainty about the level by which the prawning effort needs to be reduced, the industry has agreed to seek a reduction of 40 per cent in fishing capacity. This is equivalent to between 60 and 65 vessels. The two major mechanisms used to control fishing pressures in the northern prawn fishery have been compulsory closure of the fishing grounds now running for almost half a year and an industry inspired scheme, the voluntary adjustment scheme, whereby fishermen contribute to a levy fund which then buys out the units of fishermen leaving the industry.

The industry contributed $700,000 to the adjustment scheme in 1986 to which was added more than $1m from the Government's national adjustment fund. In 1985-86 the voluntary adjustment buy-back scheme succeeded in removing about 12,000 units-10 per cent of the total of the fishery or the equivalent of 25 licences from the northern prawn fishery. However, it has been recognised by the industry and the Government alike that progress to reduce the fishing effort has still been unsatisfactory. Consequently, it was proposed at the start of this year that the following measures be adopted to reduce further the fishing effort by the required 40 per cent by 1990: A mid-year closure from 22 June to 31 July to reduce fishing pressures on tiger prawns in the critical pre-spawning season; a ban on trawling between 0800 hours and 1800 hours each day from 1 August to 31 Oct- ober; restrictions on gear, reducing the number of nets towed by each boat to two only; and upgrading the voluntary adjustment scheme to buy out fishing capacity which can be measured in fishing units. This will be achieved by a 300 per cent increase in the 1987 levy on northern prawn fishermen.

At this point I emphasise the fact that the industry, by and large, agrees with the proposals. Indeed, the industry formulated it. It has not adopted a head in the sand approach to the problem. It is aware of the need to reduce the fishing effort and is committed to taking practical steps to do just that. However, the next part of the new plan is the crunch. If there is no reduction in the number of fishing units by 40 per cent to 70,000 units by March 1990, the Government proposes that the units remaining in excess of the 70,000 are to be acquired without compensation on a pro rata basis by all unit holders in the northern prawn fishery. This section of the plan has been introduced without adequate consultation with the industry. In other words, the Government is going to take these people's property which they rely on for a living without any compensation whatsoever.

Nowhere else in Australia, or for that matter overseas, has any government when introducing a rural adjustment scheme resorted to a compulsory surrender or acquisition of licences governing production without any form of compensation. This throws out the window one of our basic beliefs-the right to be compensated for loss of property. It would particularly damage the small fisherman-the person with only one or two vessels. The larger owners with fleets of ten or more vessels would not suffer as much as they could average their losses out amongst their boats. But let me make it quite clear that even the larger fishermen, the 10 or 15 boat fishermen, are totally opposed to this acquisition by the Government. How can any small businessman be expected to survive when 40 per cent of his assets are removed? How can any small businessman hope to get a decent selling price when all his capital, and the fishing vessel, is rendered virtually worthless? Who will purchase the vessel without a licence? All the other Australian fisheries are full and there is no way that the fishing vessel can be used in any other fishery in Australia.

Apart from the inequity of compulsory surrender without compensation, this provision will render ineffective the voluntary adjustment scheme. It will make the buy back scheme totally unworkable. The current price of a fishing unit is between $400 and $600. However, because the price of these units will soar as fishermen become desperate to build up an excess of fishing units before the compulsory reduction, the funds in the buy-back scheme will have no chance to cover the cost of purchasing the units. Industry expects the cost of fishing units to reach around $2,000 a unit-a clearly unrealistic figure. This rise in unit value will be caused solely by the compulsory surrender provision. The buy-back scheme is already being hampered by the decision of the Australian Fisheries Service which said that during the period of adjustment from 1987 to 1990, any unit surrendered to the buy- back scheme or the VAS would become a tradeable property right of the person involved in the surrender. This means that a surrendered unit can be freely traded a second time within the industry to other fishermen who may require a percentage surrender in 1990. In effect, the surrendered unit is compensated for twice and the effect on reducing the effort and the proportion necessary to remove the 70,000 units is halved. The Australian Fisheries Service must address this problem and not allow surrendered units sold to the voluntary adjustment scheme to be resold.

The Australian Fisheries Service says that the buy-back scheme has become the price setter for the purchase of fishing units. However, the marketing of fishing units at the moment shows that this is not the case. During the month of March when figures were last available, units were selling for around $600, yet the buy-back scheme has been buying units at only $450. This makes a nonsense of claims that the buy-back scheme is the price setter for fishing units. What has caused the price to increase is the threat of compulsory surrender and the sudden and urgent need for fisherman to gain an extra 40 per cent of fishing units to remain viable.

It has been suggested that fisherman can prepare themselves now for the compulsory reduction in 1990 by selling 40 per cent of their fishing units to the buy-back scheme. This is clearly ridiculous. All the fishermen need 100 per cent of their entitlements to remain viable. It is not feasible to say: `Cut your earning capacity by 40 per cent'. No normal businessman can survive that and remain in business. It is a classic example of bureaucratic unreasonableness. The only people who can sell at the moment are people leaving the industry and the very few owners with excess units. Trade in the units has come to a dead halt. The reason is that people who have units to sell are hanging on to them because they know that these units will dramatically increase in value if the compulsory surrender provision is put into place. The fishermen of the northern prawn fishery recognise the need to reduce the fishing effort. They are prepared to take these steps to reduce the fishing effort. However, they are firm in their opposition to the compulsory surrender provision. They will take High Court action to challenge this plan if the regulation is allowed. That is because the plan threatens their livelihood. They will go to great lengths to prevent it. Eighty-two independent fishermen have already banded together ready to go as far as the High Court unless this regulation is allowed.

I point out that the Government is flying in the face of its own consultative committee, the Northern Prawn Fishery Management Advisory Committee, NORMAC, in putting on to the agreed plan the compulsory surrender provisions. I have a copy of a resolution from NORMAC which endorses the gear restrictions, extended closures, bans on daylight trawling, increases in the VAS levy and the boat disposal scheme, but specifically rejects the surrender compensation provisions. I seek leave to table the document.
Leave granted.

TALK.START.PARA: —This resolution was signed not only by all the processors and fishing representatives but also by the Queensland Department of Primary Industry representative and the Commonwealth Scientific and Industrial Research Organisation. The Minister for Primary Industry (Mr Kerin), in a letter dated 14 January this year, said:

SPEECH.PARA: I am advised that the Committee's recommendation with respect to the new management arrangements for redressing the excessive exploitation rate of the tiger prawns in the fishery were agreed unanimously towards the end of the Canberra segment at the meeting of NORMAC.
As the resolution from NORMAC shows, and as the 90-odd telexes that the Minister's office has received opposing the plan show, this is just not the case.

It took until early last month for the Minister to meet with the industry representatives to discuss this problem, and the meeting was inconclusive. Now his Department is attempting to ram into place a system which has no support from the users. The reduction plan cannot work if it does not have the support and the co-operation of the industry. The seizure of people's property and assets without compensation and the implementation of a scheme which no one in the industry can honestly comprehend is being done through a mechanism which is grossly unfair.

I have amended the original motion not to disallow all of the management plan but to restrict the motion to disallow only those sections which deal specifically with the compulsory surrender of units scheme. The other parts of the plan, the increase in the levy, the extended closures, the gear restrictions, and the ban on daytime trawling, all remain in place and can be put into practice. I have done this to allow no disruption to the industry and to start the process of reducing the fishing effort straight away. All that this motion does is remove those sections which refer to the compulsory surrender provisions and the reduction in units scheme. This motion of disallowance will move an unjust and hastily thought out element of the constructive plan which apart from this section has the full support of the industry it will affect. It will give the northern prawn fishery a chance to restructure itself through the voluntary adjustment scheme, and it will remove an unjust and dangerous attempt to seize people's property without compensation. I commend the motion of disallowance to the Senate.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Archer Sen B.R.

TALK.START.PARA: —I too would like to support Senator Boswell's motion. I find it most regrettable that there is a problem of this nature. Earlier today I had one of those friendly approaches from Senator Walsh indicating that he did not quite agree with me on the approach that I was about to take. He demonstrated that he did not even know what he was talking about. In view of the fact that he was not here when the debate started tonight, I point out to him that we are talking about paragraphs 6.1, 9.1, 9.2, 9.3, 9.4, 9.5, 10.1, 10.2, 10.3, 12, 14.1, 14.2 and Schedule 1. Seeing that Senator Walsh was listening so attentively while I was going through that list, perhaps I ought to read it again-but I will not bother. If Senator Walsh had demonstrated any idea that he even knew what the motion was about, I would take him more seriously now and in the future. I assume, however, that somebody must have told him something, because he would not have had the opportunity to pick it all up on his own. It would make it easier if we could all start by talking about the same thing.

SPEECH.PARA: I regret very much that this problem does exist. I regret it because there is no doubt that the Minister for Primary Industry (Mr Kerin) has, by and large, tried to be of assistance to the industry, and I respect that very much. I am sorry that for one reason or another the communication service has broken down-and broken down badly in this regard. This particular problem goes back into last year. Since then there has been far too much talking and not enough listening. The position has not changed and the present problems exist only because they were made out to be much worse last year. Prawn problems are not new. One only has to go back to people such as Bob Mostyn to find out that prawning in the Gulf entails certain hazards. One could follow up the next 500 fishermen to have that statement vouched for.

When I came into this Parliament in 1975 there were major problems with the industry then. I have spent quite a bit of time during the intervening period talking to people who had those problems. There was little co-ordination, and co-operation left much to be desired. As I recall, Senator Walsh may, for some of the time, have been a member of the Committee on Trade and Commerce at the time we were investigating aspects of the fishing industry. Those people at that stage felt very much out on a limb, that nobody cared for them, that they were regarded as a bunch of hill-billies, and some of them even behaved accordingly. The Committee's investigations made them realise that they were part of it, that people did care, that efforts were being made to try to get the industry into a lively and worthwhile form. I have to give credit to many of the major operators, because I believe that the big people in the business have behaved very well towards the small ones. The small operators have been protected, they have received extra units in the deal because they were small, they have paid reduced levies, and they have had the inside run. It should not go unnoticed that the larger operators have acted in this way. The establishment of units has been too generous. We recognise that and the industry recognises that. Once in, the problem is having these units reduced. In this regard I particularly commend Peter Pownall, who I am glad to see is in the gallery tonight, for the efforts he has made in trying to get people to understand the problem and do something about it, and to get them organised.

The buy-back scheme has been developed. It has started and it can be made to work. It has the support of the fishermen. No one has any doubts that the effort in fishing has to be reduced and that conservation is absolutely paramount. One of the major problems is that the biology of the banana and the tiger prawn leaves much still to be learnt. Very little is known of it, and although there is, for instance, a very good catch of banana prawns right now, it is not known how long it will last or how it will be next year, and we do not know what effects the seasonal conditions will have on later runs of tiger prawns. Because of the situation, the fishermen have said that they will agree to a reduction in nets, to an extended closure period, to the banning of daylight hours fishing and to a limit of 70,000 units. When I was first made aware of the problem in plan of management No. 12, I had discussions with various people involved in the industry and I made it clear that I was not going to support any move that left an open-ended situation that would not ultimately provide for a reduction in the fishing units to the level that had to be achieved. I am pleased to say that I have been given that absolute undertaking by the industry representatives and that they will, using the methods that they have before them, achieve exactly that.

I think the fishermen need to be reminded that, far from being that outpost rabble of 12 to 15 years ago, they are now a very strong, well-organised, highly commercial and business-like group. Take my word for it-they are not peasants. They deserve great credit for the effort that they have put in. They have done a marvellous job in becoming now what is probably the best planned and best organised group in Australian fishing. I have a huge file of correspondence and documents. I am satisfied that the fishermen most of all know their case and know it very well. SPEECH.SPEAKER: Powell Sen J.F.

TALK.START.PARA: —I rise to support the disallowance motion moved by Senator Boswell and note that the Northern Prawn Fishery (Special Provisions) Management Plan was tabled on 17 February and that Senator Boswell first moved a disallowance motion on 19 March. That motion was to disallow the whole of the management plan which had been tabled. The objectives of that management plan are worth looking at. They are to reduce by 1990 the total number of class A units, including surplus units and suspense units, by not more than 70,000; to reduce by February 1990 the number of class B units and class C units by approximately 40 per cent; the prevention of an increase in the number of boats in the fishery; and the collection of a levy in relation to that program. To us they seemed to be laudable objectives. We took particular note of the factors underlying the measures in the management plan for attaining those objectives. According to the plan, those factors were said to be `Scientific advice that there is a need to reduce the fishing effort in the managed fishery to enable the stocks of tiger prawns to recover from their present depleted condition'. It was in respect of that point that we looked very closely at the original disallowance as moved by Senator Boswell. We had particular concern with that because, as was pointed out in the plan, there was seen to be a problem with the tiger prawn resource itself. We were most concerned about that.

SPEECH.PARA: The fact that tiger prawn stocks in the Gulf of Carpentaria are threatened by over-fishing is recognised not just by the Government but also by the industry. The fact that an orderly reduction in the number of boats is essential if the fishery is to remain sound seemed to us to be quite self-evident. As a result of this reduction, the prawn stocks would be given an opportunity to recover. We were aware, and we have become increasingly more aware, of the efforts which the industry was prepared to undertake and of the concern which is shared by the industry for its resource. This is not unnatural because any responsible industry, particularly any responsible primary industry, must have a real concern if it is to expect to survive. So it is no surprise that the industry itself shares that basic concern.

It is a fact, as has been already stated in the debate so far, that the industry itself had already played a significant role in accepting, supporting and, indeed, moving for the introduction of drastic effort reducing and other measures to protect the resource and to allow it to regenerate appropriately. These measures, as has been stated already, included the closing of the whole fishery for nearly six months in 1987; gear restrictions involving a reduction from four to two in the number of nets able to be used from; and a three-months ban on daylight trawling during the tiger prawn spawning season.

In particular, one of the strongest pieces of evidence of the industry's concern and preparedness to act to take very concrete action is its own financial commitment in terms of the establishment and support of the voluntary adjustment buy-back scheme. That scheme has seen a very large financial input from the industry itself-$900,000 in 1986 and a preparedness for a 300 per cent increase to $3m in 1987. Given all that, naturally we were nonplussed with the suggestion that the whole plan, which incorporated all of those measures to assist the industry, should be disallowed. However, Senator Boswell's subsequent amendment came before us on 1 April. That amendment basically sought to remove section 3 and allied clauses-that section of the plan which sets up the system for reduction units.

It is perhaps very important to understand what the impact of this particular exercise was seen to be by the industry. Basically, reduction units in practical terms are really a measure of an operator's progress towards his surrender liability, to get boats out of the fishery by a means which the Government had wanted to put in place but not by the means supported by the industry-that is, through the voluntary buy-back system. I think it is perhaps useful to look at the history of the voluntary adjustment scheme. We should realise that we have here a very important Australian primary industry which has been prepared to face the reality which unfortunately faces a great many sectors of our primary industries-the reality of restructuring the reality that because of the nature of the resource, because of the history of the industry and for the sake of its future, the industry needs to take steps to see that it becomes more efficient, more effective and that it preserves its own resource.

Indeed, the voluntary buy-back adjustment scheme was first proposed by the Northern Fishing Companies Association Ltd in a submission to the advisory body, the Northern Prawn Fishery Management Committee, in February 1983. The industry does not see this as a problem that has arisen recently. The industry endorsed in principle the proposal which was implemented in 1984. In so doing, the industry agreed, as I have said, to fund the scheme itself by way of a levy to be collected by the Commonwealth. The appropriate committee was established and the system has been coming to grips with its responsibility in the meantime.

That is not to say that the operation of the scheme is now, or has been, perfect. It has been a very concrete exercise by the industry which we believe should be encouraged and supported. As I said, the industry has agreed to a very steep increase from its own funds going into that scheme to see that it can work. We have examples from overseas and Australia of buy-back schemes. Such a scheme in South Australia to reduce the number of trawlers in the Gulf of St Vincent prawn fishery proved successful for government and industry. It is worth looking at such examples. The Northern Territory barramundi fishery in the 1970s was another successful example of a voluntary industry scheme which we believe should be supported.

However, having established such a scheme it is important that it should be effective. The Australian Democrats appreciate that a letter from the office of the Minister for Primary Industry (Mr Kerin), which was sent to a colleague in the Senate, has expressed the Government's concern in these terms:
The real question is whether the control of the fishery through such measures-
as those that I have outlined-

is acceptable in the national interest. Fishermen in the northern prawn fishery are highly protected and highly regulated. The introduction of these additional restrictions on efficiency without a real attack on the problems of overcapacity means that these additional regulations will become a permanent feature of the fishery.

That was the opinion as expressed from the Minister's office. I agree that that is likely to be the case, but only if under the voluntary scheme as outlined there is no reduction of capacity. That really is the point at which the decision needs to be made. The decision which the Australian Democrats have made is that given the efforts and the commitment-who can deny that the commitment by the industry is strong when it sinks millions of dollars of its own money into the scheme-the scheme should be given a chance. Based on history and examples from elsewhere, we are confident that if it is given a chance and if that commitment is recognised it will work in the best interests of the industry as a whole.

The impact of the imposition of the reduction unit system on top of the voluntary adjustment buy-back scheme is of great concern to us. We believe that the reduction unit scheme, through competing in a sense with the voluntary scheme, goes a long way to negating the benefits of that scheme. As an instance, the buying up of limber licences which has been a feature thus far is not reducing capacity. There is considerable speculation in the industry by a few large operators distorting the system and putting at risk that voluntary scheme which we believe needs to be given a genuine chance. People in the industry accept strongly not just the need for reduction of effort through those measures earlier stated but also a reduction in the capacity of the industry in order that the resource should not be depleted.

During consultations in the interim period we have been disturbed by the concerns of the industry at the lack of genuine consultation and the industry's feeling that its expertise and its sense of responsibility were not being recognised sufficiently. The advisory body was not being as effectively listened to as it should have been. Obviously if such schemes are to work, there is a need for co-operation between government and industry, particularly in the sensitive area of industry adjustment. It is a difficult time financially for the industry and it is difficult at a personal level for the people involved because of their great personal commitment, not to mention the financial commitment. On balance, we believe that part 3 and the allied clauses represent an overreaction by the Government, possibly with the best of intentions, to the problem of the fishing resource. We believe that the voluntary scheme is well based, well supported and needs an opportunity to work. There are distinct signs of a growing co-operation between the industry and the Government. It is encouraging that the recommendations for appointment of a consultant have been taken up and that direct discussions have finally been held between the Minister and the industry. I hope that sort of co-operation will continue.

I stress that the preservation of the resource is paramount for the Australian Democrats. We believe that concern is shared by the industry and that the voluntary scheme, that the effort reduction measures will be studiously carried out and improved and that the necessary capacity reductions will take place. If this does not happen and if between now and 1990 there is evidence before us that this is not happening, the industry and the Senate should be assured that the Democrats will act to support whatever measures may be necessary to redress the imbalance. I reiterate that we are pleased to be able to support the motion to preserve those aspects of the northern prawn fishery plan which we believe are valuable. We will vote to give the industry's voluntary scheme a chance to operate.

I have been in touch with the fishing industry in the Northern Territory, which will be one of those affected by this plan and, having discussed the matter with its representatives, I was extremely impressed to see how responsible the industry has been in relation to preserving fishing stocks. I am at a loss to see why the Federal Government is determined to undo all the good work of the fisheries industry. In doing so, it is risking the viability of an industry which is worth export earnings in excess of $200m per year.

The area involved in the northern prawn fishery runs from Cape York in Queensland across to Koolan Island in Western Australia, and, of course, it takes in northern territorial waters. The fishery is jointly managed by the Commonwealth, Queensland, Northern Territory and Western Australian governments. An advisory committee composed of seven industry representatives, officers of the Commonwealth, Queensland, Northern Territory and Western Australian fisheries departments and the Commonwealth Scientific and Industrial Research Organisation's Division of Fisheries Research advises the Commonwealth Minister for Primary Industry and the Australian Fisheries Council, which is made up of State Ministers responsible for marine fisheries, on management matters. It is most unfortunate that this advisory committee seems to have been left out in the cold in the development of the management plan for the northern prawn fishery. It is certainly clear that the industry is far from satisfied with the way in which the consultative process appears to have been abandoned or ignored by the Commonwealth Government. I note that in a letter from the Northern Fishing Companies Association Ltd to the Minister for Primary Industry, Mr Kerin, on 8 April, this year, the Association says:

We are . . . concerned about the future of Industry/Government consultation due to the breakdown in communication, particularly over the past four months. Recently NORMAC procedures have become sloppy. Minutes have been inaccurate, working groups and subcommittees have been bypassed. The proposed plan was hastily drafted for legislation without discussion with NORMAC regarding implementation.
It goes on:
Telex messages and letters sent to you-
that is, the Minister-

have remained unanswered for weeks. Letters from your office to senators on the subject have been misleading. One can only speculate as to why this lack of consultation has come about. Whether it was deliberate or through inefficiency or indifference, the Minister owes the industry the opportunity to have some real input into its own future.

As I have already mentioned, the northern fisheries industry has a very good record when it comes to initiatives geared to preserving itself and the resources upon which it relies. The industry was largely responsible for introducing the voluntary adjustment, that is, the buy-back, scheme aimed at reducing the number of licences in the fishery. The industry contributed more than $900,000 to the adjustment scheme in 1986, to which was added more than $1m from the Government's national adjustment fund. The buy-back in 1985-86 removed about 12,000 units, or 10 per cent of the total fishery-the equivalent of 25 licences.

The industry has now agreed to increase its contribution to the buy-back levy fourfold to $3m a year. In addition to this there could be a contribution from the Federal Government, as well as a loan fund which was able to be drawn on. This increased buy-back fund would enable the buy-back scheme to be extended. The fishing industry is of the very reasonable and logical view that buy-back is far more equitable than compulsory surrender without compensation for reducing the number of units and trawlers in the fishery. The industry has also accepted that the aim should be to reduce to 70,000 units by 1993.

The industry has also played a significant role in the introduction of drastic effort reducing and other measures aimed at protecting tiger prawn stocks, which became necessary after CSIRO marine scientists expressed concern that the tiger prawn stocks of the western Gulf of Carpentaria were being threatened. These measures included the closing off of the whole fishery for nearly six months in 1987; gear restrictions, that is, the reduction of the number of nets used from four to two; and a three-month ban on daylight trawling during the tiger prawn spawning season. The ban on trawling before the spawning season and other effort reducing measures are expected to achieve the required improvement in the population level in two or three generations which would be two to three years. It is encouraging to see that monitoring of tiger prawn populations in other fisheries, notably Exmouth Gulf in Western Australia, following similar effort reducing restrictions, has shown a definite increase in the size of the spawning population. This indicates quite clearly that prawn fisheries can bounce back with suitable management measures.

It is estimated that these effort and capacity reducing measures will result in a cut of 30 per cent or more in the income earned by an individual trawler-a sacrifice the industry has indicated it is willing to make to conserve prawn stocks and improve the viability of the fishery. It is very apparent that the industry is a responsible one. It realises that action is necessary to preserve the resource on which it depends. This is essential for its own survival. However, it does not accept that the Federal Minister's solution is preferable to the measures now in place on the initiative of the industry itself. Certainly, the industry objects to the way in which the Minister proposes to be able to get compulsory surrender of units without compensation, which is a fair objection on the part of the industry. As the Northern Fishing Companies Association has pointed out to me and, doubtless, to other honourable senators, the prawn fishery in St Vincent's Gulf in South Australia has been experiencing the same problems as the northern fishery. In South Australia, the State Govern- ment decided to remove compulsorily six out of the 16 vessels but with compensation.

Under a scheme similar to the northern fishery's buy-back scheme, five owners have voluntarily offered to sell their licences or licences and vessels to the Government. Compensation for licences has been as high as $450,000 and for a vessel and licence $730,000. Funds for the buy-back, in excess of $2m, were made available by the Government at commercial rates and the principal and interest will be repaid over 10 years by the trawler owners remaining in the fishery. A similar scheme operates in New Zealand. It has a voluntary buy-back scheme to remove excess trawlers from in-shore fisheries. The New Zealand Government has provided about $NZ50m for the scheme which will be repaid by vessel owners remaining in the fishery.

The northern prawning industry wants the existing voluntary buy-back scheme to be more innovative and active in removing capacity-that is units and vessels-from the fishery and has agreed to contribute $3m in 1987 to the adjustment fund to compensate trawler owners who wish to leave the fishery. This would be in addition to the finance available from a government guaranteed loan and from the national fisheries adjustment fund. That the Minister is ploughing ahead with this plan, rejecting the reasonable and sound proposals of the fishing industry, is sadly an indication of his inability properly to represent his ministerial interests. I support Senator Boswell's disallowance motion and commend it to the Senate.

SPEECH.PARA: Leave granted.
The speech read as follows-

SPEECH OPPOSING A NOTICE OF MOTION BY SENATOR BOSWELL IN THE SENATE THAT THE NORTHERN PRAWN FISHERY (SPECIAL PROVISIONS) MANAGEMENT PLAN, AS CONTAINED IN PLAN OF MANAGEMENT NO. 12 OF 19 JANUARY 1987 AND MADE UNDER THE FISHERIES ACT 1952, BE DISALLOWED.

Honourable senators, if Senator Boswell's motion to disallow Plan of Management No. 12 is carried, the consequences will be to remove the real teeth of a management plan for one of this nation's most valuable export-earning fisheries, the northern prawn fishery. Unfortunately now the Democrats have lined up with the National Party on the issue, this is the likely outcome of the debate. However the matter is of great importance and the Government intends to put its views on the matter clearly on the record.

The northern prawn fishery extends across the top of Australia taking in the waters of and between the Gulf of Carpentaria and the Joseph Bonaparte Gulf. Total prawn production is about 10,000 tonnes per year, with a value to fishermen of about $150m, and a value from exports mainly to Japan and the USA of about $180m per year. This prawn industry ranks as number two among Australia's major fishery export earners.

The fishery has been managed under a limited entry regime since 1977. In other words the Government has by regulation granted monopoly exploitation rights to a limited number of fishermen. The regulatory arrangements controlling this limited group of fishermen prior to 1984 proved to be ineffective. They were unable to adequately contain total fishing capacity or fishing effort to levels which could be safely supported over the longer term by the sustainable yield of the prawn stocks.

In 1982 the Australian Fisheries Council recognised that something had to be done and called for a review of the situation. It was clear that unless the management regime was made more effective, the northern prawn fishery would be headed for the classic sequence of events which occurs in unmanaged or poorly managed commercial fisheries around the world.

Continued ineffective management would result in a rapid escalation in the levels of fishing capacity (that is the number and sizes of boats) and effort (for example time spent fishing); the prawns would be overfished; the prawn stocks would decline; profitability to the fishermen would decline (and in fact was already happening); and eventually considerable export revenue would be lost as the fishery declined.
We could not and still cannot afford to let this happen to one of our most significant and valuable fisheries.

Since early 1984 a new plan of management for the fishery has been progressively implemented with the aims of conserving, and reducing the fishing pressure on the stocks of prawns, and promoting the economic efficiency of the fishery. These new arrangements have been developed by the Northern Prawn Fishery Management Committee which advises the Australian Fisheries Council. The Council has endorsed all aspects of the new plan.

The new arrangements were progressing well until towards the end of 1985 when it became apparent that the escalating levels of fishing capacity and effort could be causing a serious decline in the tiger prawn stocks. Tiger prawns comprise about one-third of the total annual catch and about half the total value of the catch from the northern prawn fishery.

By October 1986 CSIRO was able to confirm fears expressed by some fishermen that the tiger prawn resources in the Gulf of Carpentaria were being overfished. Clear evidence was presented at a prawn workshop in Darwin to show that an immediate reduction in fishing effort of at least 30% was essential to allow the stocks of tiger prawns to recover. It became clear in October 1986 that unless the level of fishing effort was urgently reduced, backed up by an appropriate structural adjustment to reduce the number of operational boats and the level of fishing capacity, further serious declines in the tiger prawn stocks could be expected.

To its credit, the Management Committee spent several weeks in developing a package of tough new management measures to reverse the decline in tiger prawn stocks. Its series of recommendations were endorsed by Australian Fisheries Council Ministers in December 1986. That package comprised:

(1) Immediate effort-reducing measures of extended seasonal closures (1 December to 15 April and 22 June to 31 August; about six months in total); a ban on the use of more than two nets, and a ban on daylight trawling. These measures are notified by way of Fisheries Notices under the Fisheries Act 1952.
(2) Longer term structural adjustment measures for reducing fishing capacity. These involved:
(a) a fourfold increase in the annual levy to fund the voluntary adjustment scheme for removing boats from the fishery
increasing the total levy collection in 1987 to nearly $4 million
(b) setting a target to reduce the number of Class A units of fishing capacity from 118,000 at present to 70,000 by March 1990
representing a reduction in total fishing capacity of just over 40%
and reducing the number of operational boats in the fishery from about 230 at present to between about 150 and 170 by March 1990

(c) in the event that the voluntary adjustment scheme does not achieve the March 1990 objective, only then would a compulsory cancellation of Class A units on a pro rata basis be imposed to achieve the target of 70,000 Class A units by that data
with allowance being made for those who sold part or all of their units to the voluntary adjustment scheme prior to March 1990
with compensation being paid for units compulsorily cancelled in 1990
(d) until 1990 no additional boats would be permitted to enter the fishery against currently unassigned Class B or Class C units, and

(e) the existing requirement for the surrender of a Class B or Class C unit on each replacement boat of over 375 Class A units entering the fishery would be extended to replacement boats of 375 Class A units or less.

These capacity-reducing measures have been notified in the Plan of Management No. 12-Northern Prawn Fishery (Special Provisions) 19 January 1987, and in Fisheries Levy (Northern Prawn Fishery) Regulations (Amendment) 23 January 1987.

The Government is convinced that the management package I have described will, if given the chance to work over the next three years, reverse the dangerous declining trend in tiger prawn stocks and restore the economic profitability of the fishery.

However, some members of the industry which were party to the formulation of the management package, have obviously had second thoughts about some aspects of the plan. In particular about one-third of the fishermen who by and large are single-boat owners, have campaigned hard in the past few months to have all reference to the unit cancellation scheme and its implementation removed from the plan. Their main arguments for removing the unit cancellation system are based on claims of severe hardship and inequity that the ultimate cancellation of 40% of a fisherman's unit holdings will have on single-boat owners. There are also misleading claims that `property' (i.e. fishing rights conferred on fishermen by Government regulation) will be confiscated without compensation.

The facts are that some 60-80 operational boats must leave the fishery as soon as possible. Under the proposed plan those boats would come from some single boat-owners and from some fleet operators. The burden would be equitably spread. Under the Plan of Management No. 12, there are several options open to fishermen.

For those leaving the fishery entirely, significant compensation will be paid for loss of fishing rights by those who remain. Depending on the number of units held by the seller and the price of units, compensation of the order of about $400,000 would not be an unreasonable expectation. Proceeds from the sale of the boat, if sold, would be extra. For those remaining, payment for additional units of the order of $150,000 to $200,000 may be necessary as insurance against the possibility of unit cancellation in March 1990, but that amount would be recovered later from the increased profits distributed among fewer boats harvesting the resource after 1990. For more than 50 single-boat owners who have the rights to fish in both the northern prawn and east coast trawl fisheries, the rights to continue to fish in the east coast trawl fishery will not be affected by the unit cancellation system.

I have been advised by the Minister for Primary Industry that at its last meeting in Cairns on 4 March 1987, the Management Committee reaffirmed its resolve and intent to reduce effort in the northern prawn fishery through the management measures of gear restrictions, bans on daylight trawlings, closures, increased voluntary adjustment scheme activity and levies, an industry-initiated boat disposal scheme, and restrictive boat replacement policies which had previously been recommended by the Committee. These measures are to be kept in place and will even be intensified until there is clear evidence that the breeding stocks of tiger prawns have been restored to a level that will allow the maximum yield to be safely taken each year.
The key element on which the Management Committee has reversed its earlier recommendations refers only to the unit cancellation provisions and their implementation.

The Government's view is there must be an incentive for the industry to reduce the number of operational boats over a three year period to the order of 150 to 170 compared with the 230 operating at present. Otherwise there will be little likelihood that the tiger prawn stocks will be restored to a safe medium to longer term sustainable yield. The unit cancellation system and its implementation as contained in the Plan of Management No. 12 provides for that incentive as part of a responsible approach to the effective management of this major fishery. If the Plan of Management No. 12 is disallowed, the mechanism that will ensure fishing capacity is reduced by 40% by March 1990 will be lost and the effectiveness of the Management Plan will largely be negated by maintaining more boats in the fishery than the stocks are likely to support in the medium to longer term.

The probability of cancellation without compensation is low. The cancellation mechanism simply provides the incentive necessary to decide whether to stay in a more viable fishery or sell out units (or fishing rights) to the Voluntary Adjustment Scheme or those who want to remain in the fishery. A strong incentive is necessary. Without it those in the fishery will tend to hang on; so escalating inefficiency, increasing concern about cost pressures and the impact of regulated inefficiency on profitability. The classic response to these pressures is calls for Governments to lower costs or to pay the inefficient to leave the industry. The prospect of cancellation by regulation of fishing rights created by regulation is an incentive which will ensure the necessary adjustments in ownership between fishermen takes place with minimum Government involvement and expense. Under the Government's plan a business decision, albeit a difficult one, has to be taken during the next three years to either stay in the fishery and for that benefit, pay those who must leave. Those who would leave could take advantage of the strong demand from overseas under the approach that the industry now belatedly wishes to explore, a decision to stay in or leave the fishery is not made necessary. The most likely result is that too many fishermen will remain and the biological position of the fishery and the financial situation of fishermen will gradually but relentlessly deteriorate. The National Party and the Democrats are condemning fishermen in the northern prawn fishery to slow economic strangulation.

It is a well documented feature of fisheries management around the world that politically motivated intervention in the management process-political overturning of tough management decisions-leads to the need for even tougher decisions down the road, higher costs and even more disruption usually at a time when the fishery can least afford it. Put simply, fishermen will put off a hard decision if given an opportunity. The prospect of a smaller resource in the future is all too easily dismissed as remote or someone else's problem.

There is an opportunity now for a decent exit from the prawn industry for those who must leave if it is to remain viable in the longer term. The Democrats are denying fishermen this opportunity. The record will show this. The Opposition will claim that the industry has an efficient alternative proposal but it is all words. There will be a claimed need for a `more commercial' approach to buying out boats. `More commercial' appears to mean large government guaranteed loans, government aid to sell prawn trawlers overseas to developing countries and large increases in Government levies on the industry over the next ten years. There is even the prospect of a government-owned and maintained graveyard for trawlers that have been bought but cannot be sold overseas. There has been no indication of the potential cost of the industry scheme to the industry or to government. It is not clear whether individual fishermen in the industry understand that the scheme will involve further levy increases or whether they are prepared to accept these. There are some vague ideas about new institutional arrangements to embody the new `more commercial' approach but no agreement on any of the important questions of detail. The legal and legislative implications of the alternative proposal have yet to be considered by the industry. In other words further delays in confronting the problem of excess capacity are inevitable. The opportunity to deal with the problem firmly, equitably and effectively under Plan of Management No. 12 is being lost. The alternative proposal will claim to avoid hardship on the industry. But it ignores the fact that to be effective a scheme must involve some financial hardship and some hard financial decisions either now or later. The financial hardship will be borne either by prawn fishermen or by the tax paying community. Naturally enough the prawn fishermen wish to delay any hardship as long as possible and develop arrangements which will allow them to transfer as much of the burden as possible to the taxpayer. The Democrats have allowed this to happen.

The Minister for Primary Industry has explained how the scheme would work and its benefits. He has written to the 240 northern prawn fishermen. He has met with delegations of fishermen and only last Friday held a meeting with a large group of fishermen in Cairns.

Senator Boswell and Senator Macklin were at the meeting. They heard the Government's case but rejected it. With superb, if opportunistic, political timing the Democrats, the night before the Minister's meeting announced that they would support the National Party on this issue.

John Kerin has the runs on the board in fisheries management. He understands fisheries management and that sometimes tough measures are necessary to protect a resource. He has pressed ahead with tough decisions in the past, blue fin tuna for example, with success. The National Party and Democrats do not even begin to understand the fundamental principles of fisheries management. Their lack of knowledge has encouraged fishermen in their perhaps understandable but irrational desire to put off a decision about reducing capacity. The vote on the motion, unfortunately, seems to be a foregone conclusion now the Democrats are supporting it. It is a sad day for the northern prawn fishery.
Nevertheless for the sake of effective and efficient management of the northern prawn fishery, I ask you to oppose Senator Boswell's notice of motion to disallow Plan of Management No. 12.

TALK.START.PARA: —We are witnessing here an act of economic sabotage, executed by a gaggle of economic illiterates and political opportunists. The effect of Senator Boswell's motion is to leave in the proposed package deal all those impediments to technical progress, such as gear restrictions and restrictions on daylight fishing-deliberate curbs on technical progress, impediments to increased productivity and institutionalised inefficiencies-which, in a different context, would be denounced as restrictive work practices. All of those practices which in a perfect world probably would not be in the package in the first place are to be left intact. Senator Boswell's motion removes those provisions in the proposal which ensures that what the industry really needs, which is a reduction of effort and resources committed to it, actually happens.

SPEECH.PARA: We have heard many highly misleading and emotive references to the seizure of property without compensation. The alleged seizure of property is not of real property. The proposal is that if, by 1990, sufficient units have not voluntarily attrited there will be across the board reductions in units. That is property not in any real or physical sense but a reduction in the licences granted by the Crown to exploit a resource owned by the Crown. It is a form of royalty, although it is a royalty arrangement supplied without charge.

If the people who have put up this disallowance motion are so certain that the voluntary buy-back scheme which they are proposing will achieve the required rate of attrition, the logic of the argument is that their objection to the end of the line, across the board cut in the number of units is absolutely irrelevant. Many new fisheries have gone through what is well recognised as a cycle which has its origins in, or is driven by, fundamental economic pressures. This has happened in the abalone fisheries in Victoria, in the prawn fisheries in the Gulf of Carpentaria and in the crayfish-or rock lobster as they are called these days-fisheries in Western Australia. A new market opens up for a particular edible marine species and some people exploit an abundant resource. Huge amounts of economic rent are captured by the first people who move in to exploit the resource. The very high profits very quickly attract many more new entrants.

After some point-it is usually fairly early-marginal returns on effort or investment in the fishery decline and therefore, axiomatically, average returns decline. But as long as the level of profit is above normal levels-that is, as long as any economic rent remains to be harvested-more resources continue to be poured into the industry. What ultimately happens is not just a decline in the return on investment or on effort expended but an absolute decline in the output of the fishery because of the partial destruction of the physical resource base through overfishing. What happens then is that governments move in and regulate the industry. That cycle does not always occur in a smoothly progressive way because of biological reasons, seasonal fluctuations and so on. But the trend has been repeated in fishery after fishery. This happens because of a combination of biological limitations and economic law.

It is often argued that the point at which-this assumes that it can be precisely determined, which it cannot; but let us assume for the purpose of the argument that it can-government regulations should limit output is that of maximum sustainable yield. That is a biologically correct argument or judgment. It is not, however, economically correct. In order to maximise the rent that can be extracted from the natural resource, production should be limited to a level less than the maximum sustainable yield.

The author of this act of economic sabotage, not surprisingly, is the National Party of Australia-the successor to the Country Party. The Liberal Party of Australia was given a grand opportunity last week to shed that lead from its saddlebags when the coalition broke up. It has failed to grasp that opportunity. The self-proclaimed economic rationalists of the Liberal Party are revealed, by their support of this notion, as windbags who are dancing as usual to the traditional National Party opportunistic tune. They lack the courage to take the first step towards the economic rationalism about which they endlessly pontificate.

I have often been asked why I despise the National Party so much. The reasons go back to my agricultural background. I do so for two reasons principally. Firstly, because the National Party is the only serious political party in Australia that I can remember which ever made a virtue of ignorance. The second reason is the way in which the National Party consistently betrays the interests of the people it purports to represent.

Those who are familiar with the history of the dairying industry in the 1960s will see marked similarities between the opportunistic actions of the National Party, nee Country Party, in regard to this matter and the dairy industry in the 1960s. In the 1960s, the plain economic reality was that there were about 70,000 dairy farmers in the industry. Under the conditions of that time, there may have been economic room for about half that number. However, instead of honestly telling the people who voted for it, the people it purported to represent, that the industry was overcrowded and half of them should get out while they had the opportunity to go out with a reasonable amount of money, possibly enough to buy themselves a house in a town or city and to get themselves a decent job in an era of full employment, the National Party told them: `You stick there. We will look after you. We will continue to pay the butter subsidy'.

The consequence of that action was that tens of thousands of dairy farmers inflicted a life of misery and poverty on their families. Ultimately, they had to leave the industry under less favourable circumstances and conditions than those under which they would have left the industry had they been given some decent leadership by those who claimed to represent them politically and been told the truth. That sort of history, although not precisely, is being repeated in this instance.

I have already said that, if the voluntary buy-back measures which are being advocated by the supporters of this motion of disallowance are effective, the action to which they object and which they describe quite misleadingly as seizure of property without compensation, but which is in fact an across the board reduction from 1990 onwards or in 1990 of the number of units which are still being employed in the industry, becomes irrelevant. It becomes irrelevant if the voluntary buy-back achieves the reduction in effort and of fishing units which currently operate in the northern prawn fishery.

However, if the voluntary buy-back does not work, we will be faced with this situation: There will be pressures for an intensification of the deliberate curbs on technical progress, impediments to increased productivity and institutionalised inefficiency of things such as gear restrictions and restrictions on the hours or the times of the day in which boats may operate-producing at excessive but avoidably high cost whatever output they can get. That is one of the dangers. There will be a tightening up of that institutionalised inefficiency. Secondly, there will be-this is not an alternative; it will probably go in conjunction with the former-progressive impoverishment of the individuals in the industry and an accelerated destruction of the physical resource itself, until such time as there is no internally generated surplus-that is, economic surplus or cash surplus-to buy out the operators and the equipment that must be bought out of the industry, to buy out the excess capacity which is the cause of both the falling incomes and the physical destruction of the resource itself.

It is not very hard to see what will happen under those circumstances. There will be demands on the taxpayer, on the government of the day, to put forward taxpayers' money to achieve the buy-outs which could have been achieved in an earlier period by the surplus internally generated from the industry itself. Under those circumstances, those who are most lacking in financial strength will be the ones who will be picked off most easily and forced out under much less favourable circumstances than those under which they would leave the industry if the teeth were left in the proposal; that is, if the voluntary attrition or buy-back does not work, there will be an across the board reduction in the units in 1990 or from 1990 onwards.

As the Minister in this Government who has the primary responsibility for the expenditure of taxpayers' money, I serve warning that, if I am still around when this happens, I do not believe that any responsible Finance Minister or responsible government could allow taxpayers' money to be used in 1990 to achieve a much less favourable or desirable outcome than that which could have been achieved without further injections of taxpayers' money in the period between now and 1990 if this proposal was not to be disallowed. It is to be disallowed. There is no logic in the arguments that have been put up by those who have spoken in favour of the motion and will support it; there is just a lot of political opportunism, a lot of ignorance and a lot of traditional National Party nee Country Party betrayal of the interests of the very people it purports to represent, as well as a betrayal of the national interest.

The dairy industry debacle is about to be reported on a smaller scale. This has been initiated by the successors of those who presided over the dairy industry debacle. Those who will amend, so that it effectively disallowed, the worthwhile portions of this package deal are culpable. I cannot tell the Senate what Mr Kerin will do if the proposal is emasculated. For the sake of the people in the industry, the nation and the taxpayers of the future, to whom there is a high probability of a large bill being presented at some time, albeit probably not paid, I hope that he can salvage something worthwhile from the wreckage. In closing, I repeat what I said at the beginning: What this proposal does is to leave intact the features of the package deal which really should not have been there in the first place and take out the ones that ensure that the desirable objectives of it would be achieved.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Macklin Sen M.J.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister representing the Minister for Primary Industry, upon notice, on 17 February 1987:

QUESTION.PARA: (1) Can the Minister for Primary Industry inform the Senate of the number of agricultural export transactions carried out by the European Community (EC) since 17 September 1985 which have relied on subsidies to secure contracts.

(2) Can the Minister identify the commodities involved in each transaction, the market in which that commodity was disposed of, the value and volume of each transaction, the amount of subsidy provided by the EC in each instance, and how much the eventual transaction by the Europeans undercut prevailing world prices.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Walsh Sen The Hon P.A.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Minister for Primary Industry has provided the following answer to the honourable senator's question:

ANSWER.PARA: (1) The EC is currently the world's second largest exporter of agricultural products, behind the United States. It is however, the largest exporter of a number of major products, including butter, cheese, beef, wheat flour, egg products, poultry meat and wine.

Under the EC system of agricultural price support and market management, export subsidies are payable to dispose of product on world markets whenever world prices are lower than internal EC prices. EC prices have been higher than world prices for all but brief and exceptional periods since the full implementation of the Common Agricultural Policy (CAP) in the late 1960s. The result has been that, since then, nearly every export transaction entered into by EC traders for products covered by the CAP has required the aid of export subsidies. Further information on the products covered by the CAP is given in the answer to the second part of the question.

Unit subsidy rates are usually adjusted by EC Commission market management committees weekly or fortnightly in line with fluctuations in world prices and exchange rates. These rates are set for particular product varieties and can also vary by export destination. The complexity of the resulting system is exemplified in the case of milk products where there are 374 product/destination categories.
The system also allows EC traders to ``pre-fix'' subsidy levels in advance of a sale. The period for which the subsidy may be pre-fixed also varies by commodity and by destination.

EC expenditure under the CAP is financed through advanced payments transferred each month by the Commission to the Member States of the EC. These then distribute the funds among the various paying agencies who deal directly with beneficiaries, whether these be farmers or traders. Details of individual sales are not made public as a matter of course and would be regarded by the EC as commercially confidential information.
From the foregoing it can be seen that it is not possible to provide details of the number of transactions carried out by the EC which have relied on subsidies to secure contracts.

(2) Almost all products covered by the Common Agricultural Policy are eligible for the provision of subsidies on exports to non-EC markets. These include cereals, beef and veal (certain products), pigmeat (certain products), eggs and poultry, olive oil and oilseeds, sugar, wine, fruit and vegetables and tobacco. No export support is available for flax and hemp and, although provision exists for subsidies on exports of sheepmeat, none have been applied since the inception of the sheepmeat regime in October 1980. More detailed information on the products eligible for export support measures is provided in Attachment A.

Details of the total volume and value of EC agricultural exports by destination are normally available only for calendar year periods. Information for the period since 17 September 1985 ie for calendar 1986, has not yet been released by the EC Commission. Although information on the levels of aggregate export subsidies for all eligible products will eventually be released by the European Commission in Brussels, it will not be possible to obtain details of all transactions involving export subsidies, by product and by market. Nevertheless, in order to give an indication of the magnitude of particular export subsidies, details of such subsidies per unit for a number of major products destined for specific markets are provided in Attachment B. These products are beef, butter, cheddar cheese, SMP, wheat and sugar.

On an aggregate level, in 1985 EC export subsidies for agricultural products totalled 6,588 million European Currency Units (ECU), or 33.8 per cent of total agricultural support, and in 1986 were budgeted at 8,470 million ECU, or 39.1 per cent of total EC agricultural support. It should be noted that agricultural support in this context refers to that provided by the Commission. It does not include support provided by individual member states on a national basis. An indication of the relative importance of export subsidies for particular products can be gauged from details of export subsidies and intervention support for major products or groups of products for 1985 and 1986 provided in Attachment C. It is noteworthy that, in 1985, the bulk of export subsidies (almost 88 per cent) were allocated to exports of cereals, sugar, dairy products and beef and veal.

It is not possible to give a precise estimate of the amount by which EC export prices undercut prevailing world prices because of a lack of full knowledge of all EC export transactions. It should also be noted that a universally acknowledged world price for a particular agricultural commodity over a period of time is difficult to define. There are quality differentials within some product groups and exports to particular markets can sometimes attract premiums over exports of the same product to other markets. As a result, any ``world price series'' will be indicative at best.

An indicative price series for sugar, and the GATT minimum prices for butter, cheese and skim milk powder (SMP) are provided in Attachment D to give some guide as to the relative size of EC export subsidies.

Similar series for world beef and wheat prices would, however, be difficult to construct. For beef, the world market essentially divides into those importers free of foot and mouth disease, and those not free. Two distinct price structures result with exports to the foot and mouth free markets attracting a premium compared to exports to other markets. In the main, the EC does not ship significant quantities to Australia's major markets in the foot and mouth free markets of the Pacific Basin. This is due partly to the assurance given by the EC not to apply export subsidies to exports of beef to selected East and South East Asian markets (the Andriessen Assurance). In the non-foot and mouth free markets, the EC is currently the major supplier and so is the price setter in these markets.
For wheat, the availability of subsidised product from both the United States (US) and the EC has led to substantial price discounting with a consequent distortion of overall world prices.

QUESTION.PARA: (1) Is the Minister for Industry, Technology & Commerce aware of an attempt by the National Information Technology Council to establish an Australian microcomputer system.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Button Sen The Hon J.N.

TALK.START.PARA: —The answer to the honourable senator's question is an follows:

ANSWER.PARA: Yes, I am aware of involvement by the National Information Technology Council in the development of specifications for computer systems for Australian schools.

Over the past three years, the National Advisory Committee on Computers in Schools, which was set up by the Commonwealth Schools Commission, has prepared two reports on the user needs and technical specifications for future school computer systems.

As part of the government's Computers in Schools program, the Department of Industry, Technology & Commerce has had the responsibility to ensure that Australian computer companies have the opportunity to provide a commercial perspective and commentary on these reports.

The outcome of the educator reports and the commercial perspectives will be to provide a set of guidelines on the role of computers in schools and to detail the sorts of technology which will underlie the next generation of school computers.

By involving Australian computer software and hardware companies in the exercise, the Government is giving them the opportunity to develop systems which would meet the requirements of the next generation of Australian school computers.

TALK.START.PARA: —On 24 February 1987 (Hansard, page 495) Senator Powell asked me as the Minister representing the Minister for Communications the following question without notice:

ANSWER.PARA: When will the Government complete the drafting of guidelines on public television broadcasting which commenced in 1981?
When will the Government implement Australian Labor Party policy which supports public television broadcasting?
What is the Government's timetable for the provision of suitable broadcasting facilities for those groups to start broadcasting?
The Minister for Communications has provided the following answer to the honourable senator's question:

Draft guidelines for public television were put to the Broadcasting Council for comment in 1981. The Guidelines did not proceed further because of unresolved issues relating to channel sharing and the manner of funding Public Television. These issues are currently receiving further consideration and are expected to be completed for reconsideration by Broadcasting Council during 1987.
The Government is currently considering proposals put to it recently for public television services.
A number of questions still need to be resolved. I expect to be in a position within the next few months to announce whether proposals will proceed and, if so, in what form.
